questions.text: Except for_________, all of  the following structures passes via the female inguinal canal.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Inferior Epigastric Artery
  • The inguinal canal is a passage in the lower abdominal wall that is present in both males and females.
  • It contains various structures, including nerves, blood vessels, and ligaments.
  • Inferior Epigastric Artery does not pass through the inguinal canal. It arises from the external iliac artery and supplies the anterior abdominal wall.

Other options:
  • Ilioinguinal nerve: This nerve passes through the inguinal canal in both males and females.
  • Round ligament of uterus: This ligament passes through the inguinal canal in females and helps to anchor the uterus within the pelvis.
  • Lymphatics from the uterus: Lymphatic vessels from the uterus can pass through the inguinal canal in females.


Reference-:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470204/

Bile duct/ common bile duct is divided into four parts-

3. Infraduodenal(or pancreatic) part

Arterial supply-

questions.text: Except for _______, all of the following structures cross the right ureter anteriorly.
questions.solution:

  • Except for the genitofemoral nerve, all of the other structures listed cross the right ureter anteriorly.
  • The genitofemoral nerve runs posteriorly to the right ureter, while the terminal ileum, vas deferens, and right colic and ileocolic vessels cross the right ureter in an anterior fashion.
  • The genitofemoral nerve is a nerve that arises from the lumbar plexus and descends into the pelvis.
  • It then divides into two branches, the genital branch, and the femoral branch.
  • The structures that cross the right ureter anteriorly are the terminal ileum, vas deferens, and right colic and ileocolic vessels.
  • However, the genitofemoral nerve does not cross the right ureter anteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the spinal cord is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Central canal lies in the white matter
 
  • The central canal of the spinal cord is a small, fluid-filled channel that runs through the center of the spinal cord.
  • The central canal is surrounded by gray matter, not white matter.
  • The gray matter contains neuronal cell bodies and is butterfly-shaped in cross-section, while the white matter contains nerve fibers and is located externally to the gray matter.
  • he central canal of the spinal cord is a cerebrospinal fluid-filled channel that runs the length of the spinal cord.
  • It is located in the center of the gray matter, which is surrounded by the white matter.
  • The gray matter of the spinal cord is divided into dorsal, ventral, and lateral horns.
  • The spinal cord is suspended in the subarachnoid space by a series of denticulate ligaments, which are extensions of the pia mater that anchor the spinal cord to the dura mater.
  • These ligaments help to protect the spinal cord from injury and provide support for its weight.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page No 856-860

choices.text: Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers from superior cervical ganglion
Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers in the frontotemporal branch of CN V

questions.text: What fibers supplies Dilator pupillae iridis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers from superior cervical ganglion
 
  • The dilator pupillae muscle is responsible for dilating the pupil of the eye (mydriasis).
  • The sympathetic nervous system controls the dilation of the pupil, and the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that supply the dilator pupillae muscle originate from the superior cervical ganglion.
  • These fibers travel along the internal carotid artery and reach the dilator pupillae muscle, causing its contraction and pupil dilation.
  • The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the dilation of the pupil, while the parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for constriction.
  • The superior cervical ganglion is a sympathetic ganglion located in the neck, which sends postganglionic fibers to the dilator pupillae muscle. When these fibers are stimulated, they cause the muscle to contract, resulting in dilation of the pupil.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because the Edinger-Westphal Nucleus supplies the sphincter pupillae muscle, which is responsible for constriction of the pupil.
  • Option 2 is incorrect because the Ciliary Ganglion supplies the sphincter pupillae muscle and the ciliary muscle, which is responsible for accommodation of the lens.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because the frontotemporal branch of CN V (Trigeminal Nerve) supplies the skin of the forehead, temple, and scalp, and does not have any role in the innervation of the iris muscles.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e46

  • It supports and stabilizes the superior rectus muscle, one of the extraocular muscles responsible for eye movement.
  • Helps maintain the proper position and function of the superior rectus muscle during eye movements.

questions.text: Which of the following is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females?
questions.solution:
The mesonephric (Wolffian) duct primarily regresses in females but leaves behind vestigial structures, including:

  • Gartner’s duct – Found along the lateral walls of the vagina and uterus, sometimes forming cysts.
  • Epoophoron – Located near the ovary and fallopian tube.
  • Paroophoron – Small remnants near the epoophoron.

Other options

  • The Müllerian duct (option 2) develops into the female reproductive tract (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina), not a remnant of the mesonephric duct.
  • Bartholin’s gland (option 3) originates from the urogenital sinus.
  • Round ligament (option 4) arises from the gubernaculum, not the mesonephric duct.
Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 343

questions.text: Ligamentum teres is remnant of :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Umbilical Vein
 
  • The remnant of the Umbilical Vein is the ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver).
  • During fetal development, the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetal liver.
  • Some of this blood bypasses the liver through the ductus venosus and flows directly to the inferior vena cava.
  • After birth, the placental circulation ceases, and the umbilical vein is no longer needed.
  • The umbilical vein undergoes degeneration and becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum teres.




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 230

questions.text: Which of the following concerning sarcomere arrangements is correct?
questions.solution:
The sarcomere is the basic unit of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle. It is composed of thin and thick filaments arranged in a specific pattern.
The correct option is 1, which states that the Z line is present in the middle of the I band.
The A band is the dark band seen in the center of the sarcomere and contains both thick and thin filaments overlapping each other.
The H zone is present in the middle of the A band and contains only thick filaments.
The I band is the light band seen on either side of the A band and contains only thin filaments but not the full length, it also extends in the A band.
The Z line is present in the middle of the I band and represents the boundary between adjacent sarcomeres. The M line is present in the middle of the A band and represents the center of the thick filament.
Therefore, option 1 is correct as it accurately describes the arrangement of the sarcomere.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 101

questions.text: What causes the nerve action potential to repolarize?

THE FOLLOWING MECHANISMS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR AN ACTION POTENTIAL :-
  • RESTING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL – Membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage gated Na+ & K+ channels are closed.
  • MEMBRANE DEPOLARISATION – Na+ flows INWARDS.
  • MEMBRANE REPOLARISATION –Na+ inflow STOPS. K+ flows OUTWARDS
  • MEMBRANE HYPERPOLARISATION -K+ gates are slow to close à Excess K+ EFFLUX occurs resulting in a period of HYPERPOLARISATION. Voltage gated Na+ channels go back to resting state. Sodium potassium pump restores the concentration of different ions.

questions.text: Which of the following periods of the cardiac cycle sees the greatest blood flow into the ventricle?
questions.solution:
Option 2, Atrial diastole, is the correct answer.
  • Option 2, Atrial diastole, is correct because during this period, the atria are relaxed and filling with blood from the veins.
  • As the atria fill, the pressure inside them increases, causing the AV valves to open and blood to flow into the ventricles.
  • This is known as the passive filling phase, and it accounts for the majority of the blood flow into the ventricles.
  • During atrial systole, the atria contract to push any remaining blood into the ventricles, but this contributes only a small amount of additional blood flow.
  • During ventricular systole, the ventricles contract to pump blood out of the heart, and during isovolumic contraction, the ventricles are contracting but not yet pushing blood out, so there is no additional blood flow into the ventricles during these periods. 
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

  •  In heart failure, the titin is less stiff and becomes a bigger protein.
  • VERY IMP:- TITIN GENE MUTATION – ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT CAUSE OF DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glomerular filtration is not true?

    • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium
    • Basement Membrane – Composed of Type IV collagen, Heparan sulphate
    • Visceral Epithelial Layer consisting of Podocyte foot process
  • Basement membrane composed of Heparan Sulphate which is negatively charged and hence prevents the entry of negatively charged molecules like albumin
  • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium prevents entry of molecules more than 100 nm in size ; slit diaphragm prevents entry of particles size more than 50 nm. Therefore Low molecular weight molecules filter easily.
  • Molecular weight of Myoglobin ( 16 kilo DA)  is much less compared to molecular weight of albumin (64kDA). Therefore Myoglobin is filtered much easily compared to Albumin.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667,668

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hunger pangs is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Typically begin 6 to 8 hours after last meal
 
  • Hunger Pangs are referred to  a series of high amplitude contractions of the stomach and small intestine  which forms  a cycle of quiescence and contractions known as the Migrating Motor Complex( MMC).
  • It plays a “housekeeping” role prior to the next meal and  contributes to the development of hunger.
  • MMC mainly originates in the stomach & can travel to the distal end of ileum which are triggered by the release of a hormone called ghrelin
  • As food moves from the stomach to the colon, the MMC washes and sweeps away the undigested food particles, cleans and prepares the gastrointestinal tract for the next meal.
  • The entire cycle of MMC occurs every 90 mins
  • It comprises 4 stages:-
    1. Prolonged period of quiescence
    2. Increased frequency of action potentials and smooth muscle contractions
    3. A few minutes of peak electrical & mechanical activity
    4. Declining activity
  • Hunger pangs typically begin 12 to 24 hours after the last meal, not 6 to 8 hours.  .
  • Hunger pangs can cause discomfort and pain in the pit of the stomach, and they can become more intense over time if food is not consumed.
  • In cases of starvation, hunger pangs may reach their greatest intensity in the first few days and then subside as the body adjusts to the lack of food. 
     


Reference:Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page no 486, 487

  • Hepcidin is elevated in the following inflammatory conditions like :-

Hypoxia leads to increase erythropoitin and that causes decrease in Hepcidin as more amount of Hemoglobin needs to be synthesized.

questions.text: Difficulty seeing nearby things may be caused by an inability to contract which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ciliary body
 
  • The process by which certain  structures of eye function to change the focal length of the eyes so that the image is clearly formed on the retina is called the ACCOMODATION.
  • Accommodation Reflex plays a very important role in seeing nearby objects.
  • The ocular structures involved in the process of Accommodation include the following :-
    • Ciliary muscle
    • Lens
    • Pupil
  • Ciliary Muscle  Smooth muscle that is  located in the middle of the eyes. It holds the lens with the suspensory ligaments and also adjusts the optical power or shape of the lens during accommodation.
  • Lens -  Transparent, biconvex in shape . It is bordered anteriorly (in front) by a ring it forms with the posterior side of the iris. The lens is held by the suspensory ligament  .  
  • Pupil - The pupil is located in the middle of the eyes, it is black in colour and constricts to prevent light rays that have diverged from touching the retina and causing blurred vision

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 190

questions.text: In terms of structured protein structure, an immunoglobulin molecule represents the following level:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: Quaternary structure
  • An immunoglobulin (antibody) molecule represents the quaternary structure of a protein.

The primary structure of a protein refers to the linear sequence of amino acids. The secondary structure includes local folding patterns such as alpha-helices and beta-sheets. The tertiary structure describes the three-dimensional conformation of a single polypeptide chain. The quaternary structure involves the assembly of multiple polypeptide chains into a functional protein complex.

Immunoglobulins are composed of multiple polypeptide chains, specifically two heavy chains and two light chains, which are held together by disulfide bonds. This multi-subunit organization classifies them as proteins with quaternary structure.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't occur when the liver's glucose content drops?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Increased levels of Fructose 2, 6-Bisphosphate

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase 1 which is the rate limiting enzyme of glycolysis.
When the glucose content of liver drops, there is increase in glucagon/insulin ratio which inhibits glycolysis by activating fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase which breaks down fructose 2,6 bisphosphate as well as by inhibiting phosphofructokinase 2 which prevents its further synthesis, thereby preventing glycolysis to take place.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: When compared to fasting for 12 to 24 hours, all of the following metabolic changes occur during prolonged fasting, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: 2. Liver gluconeogenesis increases

During prolonged fasting (beyond 24 hours to several days), the body shifts its metabolic strategy to conserve protein and rely more on fat-derived energy sources, particularly ketone bodies. Let's review each option:

  1. Brain use of ketone bodies increases – True. After 2-3 days of fasting, the brain starts using ketone bodies (produced from fatty acids) as an alternative energy source to reduce dependence on glucose.

  2. Liver gluconeogenesis increases – False. Liver gluconeogenesis actually decreases during prolonged fasting because the body prioritizes protein conservation. Initially (12-24 hours), gluconeogenesis is high to maintain blood glucose levels, but as fasting continues, ketone bodies take over as the primary energy source, reducing the need for glucose production.

  3. Muscle protein degradation decreases – True. As ketone bodies become the main energy source, muscle breakdown (which provides amino acids for gluconeogenesis) decreases to preserve muscle mass.

  4. Brain use of glucose decreases – True. As ketone body utilization increases, the brain reduces its dependence on glucose to minimize muscle protein breakdown.

    Hence, the option (2) is a false statement. 
     

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: After 12–24 hours of not eating, which of the following metabolic activities won't take place?
questions.solution:
During fasting for 12-24 hours glycogen would be slowly depleted, ketone bodies formation and free fatty acids will increase. But in just 24 hours of fasting serum proteins won't decrease. Serum protein might decrease in cases of chronic malnutrition. Thus, decrease in serum proteins is the answer.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 196.

questions.text: Which of the enzymatic processes below results in the production of both cholesterol and ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: HMG-Co-A Synthase

HMG CoA synthase catalyzes conversion of acetoacetyl CoA to HMG CoA ( 3 hydroxy 3 methylglutaryl CoA ), a step common to both ketogenesis and cholesterol synthesis.
However, in the pathway of ketogenesis, HMG CoA is further acted upon by the enzyme HMG CoA lyase which converts HMG CoA into acetoacetate whereas in cholesterol synthesis, HMG CoA is acted upon by HMG CoA reductase
(rate limiting enzyme) which converts HMG CoA to mevalonate.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 221.
