Option-B It has uracil instead of thiamine.
Option C-Sugar is ribose and not deoxyribose
Option D- Since it undergoes various modifications in the form of slicing and spicing, its molecular weight is less than that of hn-RNA.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 354.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most distinctive function of Type II Restriction Enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Cut DNA at palindromic sites 

Characteristics of restriction endonucleases-
  • Restriction endonucleases cuts both the strands of DNA at palindromic site.
  • Restriction endonuclease is specific for bacterial palindromic site.
  • Sticky/staggered/cohesive end with overhanging sequences is more helpful than blunt end without overhanging sequences.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is best for evaluating a gene's function?
questions.solution:
Option 4, Transgenic animals, is the best approach for evaluating a gene's function.
  • Transgenic animals are genetically modified organisms that have a foreign gene inserted into their genome. This gene can be specifically chosen to study the function of a particular gene or protein.
  • By creating transgenic animals, researchers can study the effects of overexpressing or under expressing a gene, as well as the effects of mutations or deletions in the gene.
  • Transgenic animals are particularly useful for studying the function of genes in vivo, which means in a living organism.
  • This approach allows researchers to study the effects of gene expression in the context of a whole organism, rather than just in isolated cells or tissues.
  • In contrast, Southern blot and Northern blot are molecular biology techniques used to detect the presence and expression of specific DNA or RNA sequences, respectively. These techniques are useful for detecting the presence or absence of a particular gene or transcript, but they do not provide information about the gene's function.
  • Gene knockout animals, on the other hand, are animals that have had a specific gene intentionally deleted from their genome.
  • These animals are useful for studying the effects of the loss of a particular gene, but they do not allow researchers to study the effects of overexpression or mutations in the gene. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 454.

questions.text: Except for _______, all of the following assays are used to estimate total serum protein.
questions.solution:
Bromocresol is not used for total serum protein estimation. Bromocresol green is used for only albumin estimation. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 5.

questions.text: A protein solution on heating forms a precipitate at about 40°C which redissolves at higher temperature. This solution is likely to contain:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bence Jones Protein

Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chain (kappa>lambda) found in urine in multiple myeloma due to decreased filtration capability secondary to renal failure.
They have a property of forming a precipitate on heating urine specimen at 40 degree C which redissolves at higher temperature. This property was used historically in the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
However, it has now been replaced with serum free light chain assays which are more sensitive in detecting even low levels of monoclonal free light chains.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 609.

questions.text: Because of the following, keratin in skin is softer than keratin in nails:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Less number of disulfide bonds
 
  • Keratin is a fibrous protein present in hair, nails and epidermis of skin.
  • Structure- Alpha helix linked by disulfide bond.
  • More the disulfide bond, harder is the keratin. Therefore, keratin in skin is softer than keratin in nails as it contains less number of disulfide bonds.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 625.

questions.text: Of the following, which one is not a phase 1 reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Conjugation 



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 558.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is diagnosed with mental retardation and self-mutilation history. Which test from the list below will aid in making the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Serum Uric Acid Levels 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.
Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: Except for________, all of the following leukotrienes are vasoconstrictors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Leukotriene B4
 
  • Leukotrienes are bioactive lipid mediators derived from arachidonic acid metabolism.
  • Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) is the only leukotriene that does not exhibit vasoconstrictor activity.
  • In contrast, leukotriene C4 (LTC4), leukotriene D4 (LTD4), and leukotriene E4 (LTE4) are potent vasoconstrictors that can cause constriction of blood vessels and contribute to inflammatory processes.
* [Extra Edge]: Functions of Leukotrienes


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 680.

questions.text: Which cytokine that causes macrophages to become activated and transform into giant cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): IFN gamma
 
  • Interferon-gamma (IFN gamma) is a cytokine primarily produced by activated T cells and natural killer (NK) cells.
  • It plays a crucial role in immune responses, including the activation of macrophages.
  • IFN gamma stimulates macrophages to become activated and exhibit enhanced phagocytic and antigen-presenting capabilities.
  • In certain pathological conditions, such as granulomatous inflammation, activated macrophages may fuse together to form multinucleated giant cells under the influence of IFN gamma.
* [Extra Edge]: Cytokines involved in granuloma formation


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 98.

questions.text: The inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hirano bodies
 
  • Hirano bodies are intracellular inclusion bodies typically observed in the neurons of individuals with Alzheimer's disease.
  • Hirano bodies are considered to be a hallmark pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease.
  • In contrast, Buschino bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes, and Lewy bodies and Lafora bodies are associated with other neurodegenerative disorders.

IMPORTANT INCLUSION BODIES



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: What is the best way to define the deletion of one alpha globin gene on one chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Alpha Thalassemia silent carrier 
 
  • The deletion of one alpha globin gene on one chromosome is best defined as alpha thalassemia silent carrier.
  • It refers to a carrier state where an individual has one deleted alpha globin gene on one chromosome but maintains normal hemoglobin production.
  • The term "silent" indicates that individuals with this condition are usually asymptomatic and do not exhibit any clinical manifestations of alpha thalassemia.
  • In contrast, alpha thalassemia trait and alpha thalassemia major involve more severe deletions or mutations in the alpha globin genes and can result in clinical symptoms and abnormal hemoglobin production.

* [Extra Edge]: Thalassemia Types


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Heavy chain disease with immunoglobin fragments in urine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
 
  • Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a syndrome in which high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyper viscosity of the blood like stroke, amarausis fugax,etc. 
  • It occurs in older adults, most commonly in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: There are Alder-Reilley bodies seen in which condition:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Mucopolysaccharidosis

Alder Reilly bodies are coarse granules seen in cytoplasm of white blood cells such as neutrophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes in mucopolysaccharidosis.

Other options:-
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis Birbeck granules is seen.
  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome coarse granules is seen in leukocytes in PBS. 



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: Large platelets and Dohle bodies in neutrophils are seen in which of the following autosomal dominant condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): May-Hegglin Anomaly
 
  • Large platelets and Dohle bodies in neutrophils are seen in the May-Hegglin Anomaly.
  • The May-Hegglin Anomaly is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by abnormal platelets and leukocytes.
  • The May-Hegglin Anomaly is caused by mutations in the MYH9 gene, which encodes for the non-muscle myosin heavy chain IIA.
  • Large platelets are a characteristic feature of this condition and can be observed on a blood smear.
  • Dohle bodies are basophilic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils and are associated with abnormal RNA synthesis.
Option A- Alder Reilly Anomaly
  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with large, dark-staining cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes and other cells.
  • Associated with defects in lysosomal enzymes and can cause skeletal abnormalities and intellectual disability.

Option B- Pelger-Huet Anomaly
  • Autosomal dominant disorder with abnormal nuclear segmentation in neutrophils.
  • Neutrophils have hypo segmented nuclei, but the condition is typically benign and does not cause significant health problems.

Option D- Chediak-Higashi Syndrome
  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with impaired lysosomal trafficking and fusion in cells.
  • Characterized by recurrent infections, partial albinism, and peripheral neuropathy. Neutrophils show giant granules and defective phagocytosis.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 907.

questions.text: What is the process by which CLL/SLL becomes DLBCL known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Richter syndrome
 
  • The process by which Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) transforms into Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is known as Richter Syndrome.
  • Richter Syndrome is a rare complication characterized by the development of an aggressive lymphoma, usually DLBCL, in patients with preexisting CLL/SLL.
  • This transformation is associated with a poor prognosis, as DLBCL is more aggressive and less responsive to treatment compared to CLL/SLL.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of Non-Hodgkin lymphomas


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text: What does the needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cholesterol Cleft
 
  • The needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signifies a cholesterol cleft.
  • Cholesterol clefts are characteristic histological findings in atherosclerotic plaques.
  • Cholesterol clefts result from the deposition of cholesterol crystals in the necrotic core of the plaque.
  • These crystals are derived from the hydrolysis of cholesterol esters by enzymes such as cholesterol esterase.

Fig: Cholesterol Clefts

Online Reference: Shah N, Nagalli S. Cholesterol Emboli. [Updated 2024 Jan 23]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556091/

questions.text: Except for______, each of the following statements concerning Anitschkow cells is accurate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease 
 
  • Anitschkow cells, also known as Aschoff cells, are modified cardiac histiocytes and are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease.
  • Anitschkow cells are large cells with a central, wavy, or rod-like nucleus (caterpillar appearance) when observed in longitudinal section.
  • In transverse sections, they show a characteristic "owl's eye" appearance due to the folding and condensation of the nucleus.
  • While Anitschkow cells are strongly associated with rheumatic heart disease, they are not pathognomonic and can also be seen in other inflammatory conditions.

Fig: Aschoff Body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which of the following liver areas is most vulnerable to ischemia damage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Centrilobular
 
  • The centrilobular (zone III) region of the liver is the most vulnerable to ischemic damage.
  • This area is the furthest from the oxygenated blood supply and thus receives the lowest oxygen tension.
  • When blood flow to the liver is compromised, such as in cases of severe hypotension or liver ischemia, the centrilobular zone is the first to be affected.
  • Centrilobular necrosis is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic hepatitis (shock liver) and drug-induced liver injury.
* [Extra Edge]: Nutmeg liver
  • Congestion of the hepatic and portal vessels may produce pathologic changes in the liver, the spleen, and the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The liver is usually increased in size and weight (congestive hepatomegaly) caused by passive congestion, greatest around the central veins Grossly, this is reflected as congested red brown pericentral zones, with relatively normal-colored tan periportal regions, producing the characteristic “nutmeg liver” appearance.
  • In some instances, especially when left-sided heart failure with hypoperfusion is also present, severe centrilobular hypoxia produces centrilobular necrosis. With longstanding severe right-sided heart failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

questions.text: Except for___, all of the following are components of Snover's triad in acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3. Cholangitis.

Snover's triad, which is associated with acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation, includes:

  1. Portal inflammation: Infiltration of inflammatory cells in the portal areas.
  2. Endothelialitis: Inflammation of the endothelial cells in the small bile ducts and portal vessels.
  3. Periportal fibrosis: Fibrosis around the portal tracts.

Cholangitis, on the other hand, is not a component of Snover's triad but is a separate condition that can occur due to bile duct complications or infections. Cholangitis is a component of Charcot's triad. 


Online Reference: 
Górnicka B, Ziarkiewicz-Wróblewska B, Bogdaska M, Odakowska-Jedynak U, Wróblewski T, Morton M, Ziókowski J, Paczek L, Krawczyk M, Wasiutyski A. Pathomorphological features of acute rejection in patients after orthotopic liver transplantation: own experience. Transplant Proc. 2006 Jan-Feb;38(1):221-5. doi: 10.1016/j.transproceed.2006.01.002. PMID: 16504708.

questions.text: Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not present in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer's disease 
 
  • Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are reactive astrocytes observed in certain conditions but not in Alzheimer's disease.
  • They are typically seen in hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.
  • Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the presence of neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuronal loss, but astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not a characteristic feature of this disease.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: All of the following, with one exception, display the Zellballen Pattern which is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Acoustic neuroma
 
  • The Zellballen pattern refers to the histological appearance of nests or clusters of cells separated by an abundant vascular stroma.
  • Conditions that display the Zellballen pattern include:
    • Pheochromocytoma: A catecholamine-producing tumor arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
    • Carotid Body Tumor: A neoplasm arising from the carotid body, a chemoreceptor organ located at the carotid bifurcation.
    • Glomus Jugulare: A tumor arising from the paraganglia of the jugular bulb.
    • Paraganglioma
Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, does not display the Zellballen pattern as it arises from Schwann cells rather than neuroendocrine cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: In order to confirm systemic amyloidosis, which of the following initial biopsy sites is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Abdominal fat 
 
  • The deposition of amyloid can occur in various organs in systemic amyloidosis.
  • The abdominal fat pad biopsy is preferred for the following reasons (Other sites - kidney or rectal mucosa, can also be used but abdominal fat is the most preferred initial site).
  1. Abdominal fat is easily accessible and has a high yield for detecting amyloid deposits.
  2. Congo red staining of the abdominal fat pad can reveal the characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light, confirming the presence of amyloid.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 264.

questions.text: Which one of the following describes shock lung?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diffuse alveolar damage
 
  • Shock lung, also known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a severe form of respiratory failure characterized by diffuse lung injury.
  • The histological hallmark of shock lung is diffuse alveolar damage, which includes two distinct phases:
    • Acute exudative phase: Characterized by the presence of hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls, diffuse alveolar edema, and infiltration of inflammatory cells.
    • Subacute proliferative phase: Characterized by fibroblast proliferation and organizing pneumonia.
  • Diffuse alveolar damage results in severe hypoxemia, respiratory distress, and bilateral infiltrates on chest imaging.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 138.

choices.text: Presence of giant cell in vessel wall

questions.text: What histological finding characterises chronic radiation pneumonitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Foam cells in the vessel wall
 
  • Chronic radiation pneumonitis is a late complication of radiation therapy to the chest, typically occurring months to years after treatment.
  • Histologically, chronic radiation pneumonitis is characterized by various findings, including:
    • Fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar septa.
    • Chronic inflammatory infiltrates composed of lymphocytes and macrophages.
    • Foam cells in the vessel wall, which are lipid-laden macrophages that accumulate within the walls of pulmonary arteries.
  • Foam cells in the vessel wall are a characteristic feature of chronic radiation pneumonitis and can lead to vascular occlusion and fibrosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can be seen in the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Malakoplakia
 
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are intracellular basophilic inclusion bodies that can be observed in the cytoplasm of certain cells in specific conditions.
  • The presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is most commonly associated with malakoplakia, a rare chronic inflammatory condition typically affecting the genitourinary tract.
  • Malakoplakia is characterized by the accumulation of macrophages with defective bacterial killing mechanisms, leading to the formation of basophilic inclusion bodies called Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. These bodies consist of undigested bacteria and calcium salts.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can also be seen in other conditions such as chronic granulomatous disease and Crohn's disease.
Other options: - 
  • Xanthogranulomatous cystitis- foam cells found
  • LCH- Birbeck granules are found
  • Tuberculosis- Caseous granuloma seen 


Fig: Malakoplakia

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 956.

questions.text: The skeletal muscle fibres are referred to as "ragged red fibres" in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Mitochondrial myopathy 
 
  • Ragged red fibers are characteristic histological findings in mitochondrial myopathies, a group of disorders caused by defects in mitochondrial function.
  • Ragged red fibers appear as irregularly shaped, enlarged muscle fibers with red-staining granules or aggregates in the subsarcolemmal region.
  • These abnormalities are visualized using modified Gomori trichrome staining.
  • The accumulation of abnormal mitochondria with impaired oxidative phosphorylation leads to the characteristic appearance of ragged red fibers.
  • Mitochondrial myopathies can present with muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, and other systemic manifestations depending on the specific genetic defect involved.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3529.

questions.text: The presence of_____characterises Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Linear grooves in the nuclei 
 
  • LCH is typically positive for CD1a, S100, and CD207(Langerin). 
  • It's characterized by cells having vacuolated abundant pale eosinophilic cytoplasm containing linear groves on the nucleus and the presence of Birbeck granules. 
  • CD15 positivity is seen in Hodgkin's Lymphoma. 
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a rokitansky protuberance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Teratoma
 
  • A Rokitansky nodule, also known as a dermoid plug, is a solid protuberance that projects from an ovarian cyst in the context of a mature cystic teratoma.
  • It often contains calcific, dental, adipose, hair, and/or sebaceous components.
  • Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and bone. They are the most common type of ovarian tumor in children and young women.
  • Dysgerminomas, yolk sac tumors, and sex cord-stromal tumors are all types of germ cell tumors, but they do not typically contain a Rokitansky nodule.




Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5359144/

questions.text: Which of the following would indicate a mixed connective tissue disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): UI-RNP antibody
 
  • Mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD) is a rheumatic autoimmune condition that shares features of several connective tissue diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.
  • MCTD is characterized by the presence of high titers of antibodies against U1 ribonucleoprotein (UI-RNP antibody).
  • The UI-RNP antibody is specific to MCTD and distinguishes it from other connective tissue diseases.
  • Clinical features of MCTD include joint pain, Raynaud's phenomenon, muscle weakness, and a high prevalence of pulmonary hypertension.
  • MCTD typically has a good response to treatment with immunosuppressive agents.
* [Extra Edge]: Various Autoantibodies associated conditions



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 234.

questions.text: Where is Keratoderma Blennorrhagica frequently found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Reactive Arthritis
 
  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a skin manifestation that can occur in reactive arthritis, a form of arthritis associated with certain infections, such as Chlamydia trachomatis or gastrointestinal infections.
  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica is characterized by the presence of hyperkeratotic plaques and pustules on the palms and soles.
  • The lesions may be erythematous and have a yellowish or grayish appearance.
  • Other common features of reactive arthritis include asymmetric oligoarthritis, enthesitis, and uveitis.
  • The presence of Keratoderma blennorrhagica can help support the diagnosis of reactive arthritis.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1045.

questions.text: Lupus Pernio is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sarcoidosis
 
  • Lupus pernio is a distinct skin manifestation of sarcoidosis, a multisystem granulomatous disorder.
  • It presents as violaceous, indurated, and raised plaques on the face, particularly involving the nose, cheeks, and ears.
  • Lupus pernio lesions are typically chronic and resistant to treatment.
  • The presence of lupus pernio is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis, although it is not specific.
  • Sarcoidosis can involve various organs, including the lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes, and liver.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: Which organ has carcinomas that have the highest serum levels of acid phosphatase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Prostate
 
  • Carcinomas of the prostate have the highest serum levels of acid phosphatase among the listed options.
  • Acid phosphatase is an enzyme that is normally present in various tissues, including the prostate gland.
  • In prostate cancer, cancer cells disrupt the normal architecture of the prostate, leading to the release of elevated levels of acid phosphatase into the bloodstream.
  • Elevated serum levels of acid phosphatase are commonly used as a marker of metastatic prostate cancer and can be used to monitor treatment response.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 977.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest antiseptic resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Prion

Prion is known to have the highest antiseptic resistance as they do not contain nucleic acid, unlike bacteria, fungi, viruses, and other pathogens. They are therefore resistant to procedures that destroy pathogens by breaking down nucleic acid. Furthermore, because these particles are an abnormal version of a normal protein that is already coded for in the body, they do not trigger a host immune response, as other pathogens do.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 560.

questions.text: A five-year-old child is diagnosed with lower leg pustules. The lesion's culture revealed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. What is a possible preliminary diagnosis of group A streptococcal pyoderma?
questions.solution:
Group A strep is beta hemolytic cocci which are sensitive to bacitracin. It is used to differentiate it from Group B Streptococci which is bacitracin resistant.
Other options-Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility are used to differentiate alpha hemolytic streptococci.
All streptococci are catalase negative.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 217.

questions.text: Which gram-negative bacteria's endotoxin  contribute to the aetiology of cholera?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Vibrio cholerae

V. Cholera produces enterotoxin A and B which contributes to the aetiology of cholera by increasing cAMP and producing more intestinal secretions.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which of the following second messengers is stimulated in order to mediate the effects of cholera toxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  cAMP

The Cholera toxin molecule has two subunits, A and B. Out of which A, on being transported to enterocytes dissociates into A1 and A2. A1 fragment activates cAMP which causes an outpouring of secretions in the intestine ultimately leading to watery diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which of these "Vibrios" is most frequently connected to ear infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: V. Alginolyticus

V. Alginolyticus is most commonly indicated in the infections of ears and eyes. It is mostly found in sea fish.
Other options- V. Parahaemolyticus is indicated in food poisoning ass. With marine food.
V. Vulnificus is associated with wound infection especially in immunocompromised.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: What is the Salmonella Typhi infectious dose?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 102 to 105 bacilli

The typical salmonella typhi infection dose is 10^2 to 10^5 bacilli.
The infection dose for non-typhoidal salmonellosis, the dose is 10^3 bacilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 302.

questions.text: What is a typical Nocardia Asteroids infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Brain Abscess

Nocardia is not known to cause the other conditions given in the options.
Cerebral Nocardiosis is a rare, challenging, opportunistic infectious disease of the central nervous system occurring in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised hosts. It often results in intraparenchymal abscess formation, which represents only 2% of all cerebral abscesses.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 400.

questions.text: Gram-stained periorbital exudates from a diabetic elderly patient with severe panophthalmitis and cellulitis show irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Apophysomyces sp
  • Apophysomyces sp. Is known to cause infection in immunocompromised individuals. Although, 80% of mucormycosis is caused by Rhizopus and Mucor, Apophysomyces is on the rise. Also, it is different from the above two in being aseptate.
  • Other options- Candida is a pseudohyphae.
  • Aspergillus and Pencillium are septate.
  • The given scenario describes a case of severe panophthalmitis and cellulitis in an elderly diabetic patient.
  • Gram-stained periorbital exudates from the patient show irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae.
  • Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis is Apophysomyces sp.
  • Apophysomyces is a type of fungus that belongs to the order Mucorales. It is commonly found in soil and decaying organic matter. Apophysomyces infections are rare but can be life-threatening, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with diabetes.
  • The fungus can invade blood vessels, leading to tissue necrosis and rapid deterioration of the affected area.
  • The characteristic irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae seen in the gram-stained periorbital exudates are consistent with the morphology of Apophysomyces.
  • Other fungal infections, such as Candida and Aspergillus, typically show different morphological features. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 614.

questions.text: Multiple leg ulcers are seen in a farmer from the sub-Himalayan area. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sporothrix Schenckii

Sporotrichosis is common in the sub-himalayan belt. It presents as diffuse erythema, multiple leg ulcers and abscess in a linear pattern due to lymphatic spread. 
Other options- Trichophyton rubrum causes dermatophytosis.
Aspergillus mostly causes respiratory infections like ABPA, Fungal ball and is also indicated in paranasal infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does T cells and B cells not share?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Positive Selection During Development

In positive selection, T cells in the thymus that binds moderately to MHC complexes receive survival signals. However, T cells whose TCRs bind too strongly to MHC complexes, and will likely be self-reactive, are killed in the process of negative selection. This property is not shown by B cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 131.

choices.text: Inappropriate Expression of MHC Class II Molecules

questions.text: How does the Epstein-Barr virus produce autoimmunity?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is thought to produce autoimmunity primarily through 1. Molecular Mimicry.

This mechanism occurs when the viral antigens resemble host tissues, leading to cross-reactivity of the immune response and potentially resulting in autoimmune conditions. However, EBV can also contribute to autoimmunity through 4. Polyclonal B cell Activation, as it stimulates B cells in a way that can lead to the production of autoantibodies. Both mechanisms are involved, but molecular mimicry is a key factor.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 481.

questions.text: A child who has bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysacchride rich capsules Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies is most likely to result in these infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: IgA + IgG2
  • Low levels of IgA can be seen with deficiencies of one or more IgG subclasses mostly IgG2. Infections by encapsulated bacteria (Hemophilus influenza and Streptococcus pneumoniae) are seen here which present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgA + IgG2 deficiency is the most likely immunoglobulin subclass deficiency to result in bacterial sinopulmonary infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules.
  • IgA is the primary immunoglobulin found in mucosal secretions and is important in preventing infections at mucosal surfaces.
  • IgG1 and IgG3 are important in opsonization and complement activation, which are important mechanisms for clearing bacterial infections. IgG2 is important for opsonization and complement activation against encapsulated bacteria.
  • Polysaccharide capsules are a virulence factor used by bacteria to evade the immune system.
  • The antibodies against these capsules are primarily IgA and IgG2.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in both IgA and IgG2 would make a person more susceptible to bacterial infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In summary, a child with bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysaccharide-rich capsules is most likely to have an IgA + IgG2 deficiency.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: A child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions. Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies has to be specifically looked into?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: IgG2
  • IgG2 infections are most commonly associated with capsulated organisms such as H. influenza. These present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgG2 deficiency needs to be specifically looked into in a child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions.
  • IgG2 is an important immunoglobulin subclass that plays a crucial role in the defense against bacterial infections, particularly those caused by encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • These bacteria have polysaccharide capsules that protect them from phagocytosis by macrophages and neutrophils.
  • However, IgG2 can recognize and bind to these capsules, facilitating opsonization and phagocytosis by immune cells.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in IgG2 can lead to recurrent infections with these bacteria.
  • On the other hand, deficiencies in IgA and IgG1 are associated with recurrent respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, but not specifically with polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgD deficiency is very rare and is not known to cause recurrent infections.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 175.

choices.text: Most common mechanism is the production of neutralizing enzymes by bacteria
Complete elimination of target binding site may be the mechanism of resistance in some enterococci against vancomycin
Alteration of target binding site leads to the development of resistance to antibiotics in streptococcus pneumonia

questions.text: All of the following statements about antibiotic resistance are true, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Plasmid-mediated resistance is exclusively transmitted vertically 

Plasmid-mediated resistance is transferred by two means - vertical transmission through cell division and horizontal transmission through conjugation. Horizontal transmission is more common than vertical.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: A foundational idea behind vaccination is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Immunologic Memory 

Vaccinations take advantage of memory lymphocyte development by artificially generating active immunity, a process called immunization. During a vaccination, the antigen of a pathogen is introduced into the body and stimulates the immune system to develop specific immunity against that pathogen. It doesn’t cause the disease that the pathogen brings because the vaccine uses an attenuated form of the pathogen that contains the same antigen but doesn’t have the capacity for replication.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

choices.text: Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay used ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can distinguish between M. tuberculosis and M. Bovis
None of the non-tuberculosis mycobacteria give a positive reaction with the test

questions.text: Which of the following assertions is true about the use of gamma release assays to diagnose tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay used ESAT-6 and CFP-10

QuantiFERON-TB Gold (QFT) is an in vitro diagnostic test using a peptide cocktail simulating ESAT-6, CFP-10, and TB7.7(p4) proteins to stimulate cells in heparinized whole blood. Detection of interferon-γ (IFN-γ) by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is used to identify in vitro responses to those peptide antigens that are associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: Except for_______, all of the following tests include Heterophile agglutination.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Rose-Waaler test

The Waaler Rose test is a slide hemagglutination method for the qualitative and semi-quantitative detection of RF in human serum. Stabilized sheep erythrocytes sensitized with rabbit IgG anti-sheep erythrocytes are agglutinated when mixed with samples containing RF.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: Standard agar is recommended for susceptibility tests using antibiotic sensitivity disks
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Muller Hinton Agar

Mueller Hinton Agar is a solid medium originally designed for the isolation of pathogenic Neisseria species. Now, it is widely used for antibiotic susceptibility testing (including sulfonamides) of aerobic and facultatively anaerobic bacteria isolated from clinical specimens.
It is a homogenous agar with a pH of 7.3

Other options- PLET - B. anthracis
Castanada agar- Brucella
Cetrimide agar- P. aeruginosa

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 43.

questions.text: Bile esculin Agar is used to identify:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Enterococcus Faecalis

Bile Esculin Agar is used primarily to differentiate Enterococcus from Streptococcus. Members of the genus Enterococcus are capable of growing in the presence of 40% bile (oxgall) and hydrolyzing esculin to glucose and esculetin. Esculetin combines with ferric ions to produce a black complex.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 51.

choices.text: Includes drugs for some uncommon diseases in developing countries

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding orphan drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Includes drugs for Rare Diseases
 
  • Orphan drugs are medications that are developed to treat rare diseases or conditions that affect a small number of people.
  • These drugs are often not commercially viable for pharmaceutical companies to develop due to the limited patient population.
  • Therefore, governments around the world have implemented policies to incentivize the development of orphan drugs.
Option 1 is correct because while orphan drugs are developed for rare diseases
Option 2 is incorrect because orphan drugs cannot include medications for uncommon diseases in developing countries. 
Option 3 is incorrect because orphan drugs are not necessarily profitable for pharmaceutical companies to develop.
Option 4 is incorrect because all drugs, including orphan drugs, can have adverse effects.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

choices.text: Receptors for which there is no endogenous mediator or ligand
Receptors which bind specific drugs but no pharmacological response is elicited

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Orphan Receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Receptors for which there is no endogenous mediator or ligand

Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

* Some of the orphan drugs are:
  • Clofazimine
  • Carboprost
  • Rifaximin
  • Rituximab
  • Busulfan
Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified. Therefore, option B is true.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 52.

questions.text:
What is the best way to define a drug's bioavailability when taken orally?
1. \(AUC intravenous \times 100\over AUC oral\)
2. \(AUC orals \times 100\over AUC intravenous\)
3. \(AUC oral \times 100\over Time\)
4. \(AUC intravenous \times 100\over Times \)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)  \(AUC orals \times 100\over AUC intravenous\)
 
  • Bioavailability refers to the extent and rate at which a drug is absorbed into the systemic circulation after administration, specifically when taken orally.
  • It is commonly expressed as a percentage and is calculated by comparing the area under the curve (AUC) of the drug's concentration-time profile after oral administration (AUCoral) to the AUC after intravenous administration (AUCintravenous).
  • Therefore, the correct formula for calculating bioavailability when taken orally is AUCoral × 100 / AUCintravenous.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: The response curve for a logarithmic graded dosage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Sigmoid
 
  • The log dose-response curve is essentially represented by a sigmoid curve if the experimentalist determines a wide range of doses and identifies the threshold or the lowest active dose, as well as that dose which produces a maximal effect.
  • Based on this, one can determine the linear portion of the sigmoid curve and thus that area in which responses can be used for comparing the effects of various other treatments (such as the effect of pH, the effect of antagonists, the effect of other agonists with similar structures, etc.).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 63.

questions.text: Select the appropriate agonist-antagonist pairing from the list of adrenergic medications.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clonidine- Yohimbine

The correct pairing from the list above is:
Clonidine is a selective alpha 2 receptor agonist. Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism.

* Other options:
  • Phenylephrine is an α1-selective agonist, Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism.
  • Dobutamine shows both α and β receptor agonism. Butaxamine (INN, also known as butoxamine) is a β2-selective beta blocker.
  • Salbutamol is a beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist. Atenolol is a second-generation beta-1-selective adrenergic antagonist



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 140.

choices.text: Fall followed by rise in blood pressure

questions.text: What is the effect of adrenaline when administered after alpha-receptors blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fall in blood pressure
 
  • Adrenaline acts on both alpha-adrenergic and beta-adrenergic receptors in the body.
  • Alpha-receptors are located in various tissues, including blood vessels, where their activation leads to vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.
  • When alpha-receptors are blocked, either by specific medications or antagonists, their vasoconstrictive effects are inhibited.
  • As a result, the administration of adrenaline after alpha-receptor blockade will predominantly activate beta-receptors, leading to vasodilation and a fall in blood pressure.
  • Beta-receptor activation also causes increased cardiac output and bronchodilation.
  • Therefore, the net effect of adrenaline administration after alpha-receptor blockade is a fall in blood pressure. The phenomenon is known as vasomotor reversal of Dale.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GI disturbance
 
  • Nitrates are a class of medications commonly used for the treatment of angina (chest pain) and certain cardiovascular conditions.
  • Nitrates primarily work by dilating blood vessels, leading to improved blood flow and reduced cardiac workload.
  • While nitrates can cause several side effects, including vasodilation-related effects, GI disturbance is not typically associated with their use.
Option 1, 2 and 4 are correct regarding Side effects of Nitrate 
  • Nitrates can cause a drop in blood pressure, especially when changing positions from lying down to standing, leading to orthostatic hypotension.
  • Nitrates can cause an increase in heart rate, due to reduced BP causing Bainbridge reflex resulting in tachycardia.
  • Tachyphylaxis refers to a reduced response to a drug over time with repeated administration. Nitrates are known to develop tolerance, and their effectiveness can decrease with prolonged use, requiring dose adjustments or drug holidays.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 587.

questions.text: Which of the following best sums up the way that Levosimendan works?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Calcium Sensitizer
 
  • This inotropic drug acts by sensitizing myocardial troponin C to Ca2+, as well as by inhibiting PDE3. It also opens ATP-sensitive K+ channels in vascular smooth muscle cells to cause vasodilatation. Thus, it is another ‘inodilator’, Haemodynamic improvement in heart failure is both due to increase in cardiac contractility as well as reduction in preload and afterload.
  • Levosimendan infused i.v. is primarily indicated for short-term treatment of acutely decompensated severe chronic heart failure. Though it relieved symptoms of heart failure, but survival rate was not improved.
  • The most common side effect is hypotension which may last for few days due to its active metabolite that has long t½.
  • Another Example is Pimobendan

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 568.

questions.text: For the treatment of dyslipidemia, cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitor is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Torcetrapib

Torcetrapib increase HDL cholesterol by inhibiting CETP (cholesterol ester triglyceride transport protein).

* Mechanism of action:
  • Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) transfers cholesteryl esters from mature, large diameter HDL particles to triglyceride rich lipoproteins that ultimately deliver the esters to liver whence both cholesterol and bile acids can be eliminated into the intestine.
  • Inhibition of CETP leads to accumulation of mature HDL particles and diminution of the transport of cholesteryl esters to liver. The accumulation of large HDL particles does not have the cardioprotective effect anticipated on the basis of epidemiologic studies.
  • Some reduction of LDL-C can be achieved and cholesterol efflux capacity enhanced. 

* Examples:
  • Torcetrapib
  • Anacetrapib 
* Adverse Effects: 
Adverse effects may have included hypertension, other non-mechanism related adverse vascular effects, and the putative decrease in ABCA1-mediated cholesterol efflux reflecting diminished lipid exchange-lipolysis of HDL particles.

The development of torcetrapib has been halted as it showed increased mortality in the ILLUMINATE trial.

Trick:- 
TorCETraPib- CETP inhibitor

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 638.

questions.text: All of the following are first-line medications for the therapy of hypertension in patients with no additional comorbidities with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Beta-blocker
 
  • Mainly due to inferior efficacy in primary prevention of MI and stroke, as well as other drawbacks like there are several contraindications to β blockers, including cardiac, pulmonary and peripheral vascular disease.
  • The nonselective β blockers have an unfavorable effect on lipid profile that's why b blockers are no longer considered first line antihypertensive drugs for monotherapy, except in patients with other compelling indications (JNC 8, NICE guidelines 2011) - Stable heart failure, post-myocardial infarction, High coronary artery disease risk etc.

Option 1, 3 and 4 are all First-line medications for the therapy of hypertension in patients with no additional comorbidities typically include ACE inhibitors, calcium channel blockers, and diuretics.
  • These medications are commonly recommended due to their efficacy, safety profiles, and ability to lower blood pressure effectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 610.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is least effective in lowering blood pressure when used with Thiazide diuretics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Calcium channel blockers 
 
  • Thiazide diuretics are a class of drugs that are commonly used to treat hypertension.
  • They work by increasing the excretion of sodium and water in the urine, which leads to a decrease in blood volume and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure.
  • Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are another class of drugs that are often used to treat hypertension, and they work by blocking the entry of calcium into smooth muscle cells, which causes relaxation of the blood vessels and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure.
  • When used together, thiazide diuretics and CCBs have a synergistic effect on blood pressure reduction. However, the other options - ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and beta-blockers - are also commonly used in the treatment of hypertension and can be used in combination with thiazide diuretics to reduce comorbidities.
  • Therefore, the correct answer to this question is option 4 - Calcium channel blockers. This is because calcium channel blockers in combination with thiazide diuretics can cause hypokalemia, hence the combination is not preferred.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 615.

questions.text: What is known as "peakless" insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Insulin Glargine
 
  • Insulin Glargine, a long-acting insulin analog, is commonly referred to as "peakless" insulin.
  • It is designed to provide a continuous and steady level of insulin activity over an extended duration.
  • Unlike some other insulin formulations, Insulin Glargine has a relatively flat and prolonged action profile, which means it does not have a distinct peak in its activity.
  • This steady release of insulin helps provide basal insulin coverage throughout the day and night, mimicking the body's natural basal insulin secretion pattern.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 287.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pethidine or meperidine is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Has pronounced Antitussive action
 
  • Pethidine or meperidine is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain relief.
  • While pethidine does have antimuscarinic effects (option A), meaning it can block the actions of acetylcholine, leading to potential side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision
  •  It does not have pronounced antitussive action (option C).
  • Antitussive medications are used to suppress or relieve coughing.
  • Pethidine is known for its analgesic properties and its ability to relieve pain, but it is not considered a primary antitussive medication.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 503.

questions.text: What is most frequently linked to pill induced esophagitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Doxycycline
 
  • Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill.
  • Among the options provided, doxycycline is most frequently associated with causing pill-induced esophagitis.
  • The mechanism behind doxycycline-induced esophagitis is thought to be related to its direct irritant effect on the esophageal lining and the potential for local tissue damage.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs causing esophagitis 
  • Doxycycline
  • Quinidine
  • Phenytoin
  • NSAIDs
  • Bisphosphonates
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems should not be used to treat nosocomial infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ertapenem
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: Ertapenem does not work well against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pseudomonas
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: When compared to vestibular toxicity, which aminoglycoside is more toxic to the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kanamycin
 
  • Aminoglycoside antibiotics are known to have the potential for both vestibular and cochlear toxicity, which can result in balance and hearing disturbances, respectively.
  • Among the given options, kanamycin (option C) is generally considered to have a higher risk of cochlear toxicity compared to vestibular toxicity.
  • Cochlear toxicity refers to damage to the structures of the inner ear responsible for hearing, while vestibular toxicity refers to damage to the structures responsible for balance and spatial orientation.
  • The decreasing order of potency for neuromuscular blockade: Neomycin -> Kanamycin -> Amikacin -> Gentamicin -> Tobramycin
Cochleotoxic drugs- KAN ( meaning ear)
Kanamycin 
Amikacin 
Neomycin- most toxic 

Vestibulo-toxic drugs-
Streptomycin
Gentamycin 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 795.

questions.text: What is Gramicidin S?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cyclic Decapeptide 
 
  • Gramicidin S is an antibiotic peptide composed of 10 amino acid residues, making it a cyclic decapeptide.
  • It is produced by the soil bacterium Bacillus brevis and has potent antimicrobial activity against a wide range of bacteria.
  • Gramicidin S is known for its ability to form ion channels in cell membranes, disrupting the normal functioning of bacterial cells.
  • Due to its mode of action, gramicidin S is primarily used as a topical antibiotic and is not typically administered systemically.
  • A group of peptide antibiotics from BACILLUS brevis. Gramicidin C or S is a cyclic, ten-amino acid polypeptide and gramicidins A, B, D are linear. Gramicidin is one of the two principal components of TYROTHRICIN.
Online Reference: 
PubChem [Internet]. Bethesda (MD): National Library of Medicine (US), National Center for Biotechnology Information; 2004-. PubChem Compound Summary for CID 73357, Gramicidin S; [cited 2024 Sept. 14]. Available from: https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Gramicidin-S

questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug among the following has the highest sterilising effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • Rifampicin has a high sterilizing effect, meaning it is effective in killing both replicating and non-replicating bacteria, including those in the dormant or persistent state.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • This unique mechanism of action contributes to its high sterilizing effect, reducing the bacterial load in TB infection and facilitating the eradication of the disease.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Which antitubercular drug among the following has the best chance of halting the development of isoniazid resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • When used in combination with isoniazid, rifampicin has been shown to reduce the risk of the development of isoniazid resistance.
  • The combination of rifampicin and isoniazid is often recommended as a frontline therapy to prevent the emergence of drug resistance and improve treatment outcomes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for tuberculosis during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) HRZE for 2 months followed by HRE for 4 months according to NTEP
 
  • The preferred treatment regimen for tuberculosis (TB) during pregnancy follows the same principles as non-pregnant individuals, aiming to provide effective treatment while considering the safety of the mother and fetus
  • This treatment regimen provides adequate drug coverage to effectively treat TB while reducing potential risks to the mother and fetus.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 827.

questions.text: Rifampicin is being used to treat a patient. In the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment, which of the following medicines is not preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nevirapine
 
  • Rifampicin, a key component of tuberculosis (TB) treatment, can significantly affect the metabolism of certain antiretroviral drugs used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS.
  • Rifampin, phenytoin, and nevirapine are microsomal enzyme inducers. Nevirapine, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), is known to have a significant interaction with rifampicin.
  • Rifampicin can enhance the metabolism of nevirapine, leading to decreased plasma levels and potential loss of efficacy.
  • Due to this drug-drug interaction, nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based TB treatment.
  • Rifampicin is a medication commonly used to treat tuberculosis, and it is also a potent inducer of certain liver enzymes. These enzymes can increase the metabolism and decrease the effectiveness of other medications that are metabolized by the same enzymes. In the case of HIV treatment, Rifampicin can reduce the effectiveness of certain antiretroviral drugs, including Nevirapine. As a result, Nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
  • Instead, other antiretroviral drugs that are less affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction are preferred, such as Efavirenz. Therefore, option 2 is the correct answer. Zidovudine and Lamivudine are both nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), which are not affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction. These drugs are commonly used in HIV treatment and are not contraindicated in Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 864.

choices.text: Treatment should be initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset
Should not be co-administered with the vaccine
Orally active with a Bioavailability of >60 percent

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning oseltamivir is correct except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Should not be co-administered with the vaccine 
 
  • Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor (option A) and is commonly used for the treatment and prophylaxis of influenza virus infection.
  • It is most effective when initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset (option B), as early treatment can help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.
  • Oseltamivir can be co-administered with the influenza vaccine (option C), and there are no significant interactions between oseltamivir and the vaccine. In fact, it is often recommended to receive the influenza vaccine even while taking oseltamivir for treatment or prophylaxis.
  • Oseltamivir is orally active, meaning it can be taken by mouth, and it has a bioavailability of over 60 percent (option D). This indicates that a significant portion of the drug is absorbed and available for therapeutic effect when taken orally.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.

questions.text: The skull's minimum anterior-posterior diameter is in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3 Brachycephaly 
 
  • Brachycephaly is a condition in which the skull is relatively short and wide, with a cephalic index (ratio of the maximum width of the skull to its maximum length) of over 80%.
  • This means that the minimum anterior-posterior diameter of the skull is relatively short compared to the maximum width.
  • The opposite of brachycephaly is dolichocephaly, in which the skull is relatively long and narrow, with a cephalic index of less than 75%. Mesaticephalic skulls have a cephalic index between 75% and 80%.
  • Trigonocephaly is a condition in which the skull has a triangular shape due to premature closure of the metopic suture.
Cephalic index is maximum transverse breadth of skull divided by maximum anterio-posterior length of skull multiplied by 100.
Based on CI, 3 types of skull-
1. Dolicho-cephalic (Long headed)- 70 to 74.9, Negroid
2. Mesati-cephalic (Medium headed)- 75 to 79.9, Caucasians, Chinese, Indians
3. Brachy-cephalic (Short headed)- 80 to 84.9, Mongoloids

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 56.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used for demonstrating old washed up blood-stains
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Luminol spray

Luminescence test is used to identify very dilute form of blood stains. It is positive even in old washed stains.

Other tests:

choices.text: Imprisonment for one year and /or fine of Rs. 1000
Imprisonment for two years and /or fine of Rs. 5000
Imprisonment for one month and /or fine of Rs. 500

questions.text: Upon being provoked, person "X" swings a wooden stick at person "Y." A 3 cm x 3 cm bruise develops as a result on the forearm. No other wounds are reported. Which of the following statements about his punishment is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Imprisonment for one month and/or fine of Rs. 500 

This is an act of voluntarily causing hurt on provocation. IPC section 334 states: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt on grave and sudden provocation, if he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause hurt to any person other than the person who gave the provocation, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: Which of the following sections of the IPC protects the disclosure of a rape victim's identity?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Section 228A.

Any medical officer or police personnel is punishable under section 228A if he discloses the identity of a rape victim.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 413.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to evaluate hymen rupture in rape victims and identify whether it is recent or not?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Glaister Keen Rod.

To determine the degree of hymnal rupturing and whether it is recent or old, a glass rod with a small spherical head known as Glaister keen rod is introduced into the vagina.

The examination of a rape victim is done according to 164A CrPc
  • First Aid treatment to be given immediately
  • Police intimation should be done
  • Consent is mandatory. No examination without consent
  • Informed refusal should be taken
  • Sexual assault forensic examination (SAFE) kit used for examination and collection of all evidences.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: A sodomy suspect is brought in for a medical examination. He admits that he is an active agent and a frequent participant after thorough inquiry. Which of the following will not be observed during the accused's examination?
questions.solution:
Findings of local examination in an active agent of sodomy-
1. Elongated penis with constriction of shaft at a distance from glans which implies habitual active individual.
2. Twisted urethra
3. Redness and swelling due to friction.
4. Traces of feces (smell of feces) and lubricant.
5. Frenulum tears
6. Presance of blood, seminal stains, foreign hairs or venereal disease.
7. Abscence of smegma after the recent act.

Urethral swabs- smears from the external meatus may show presance of feces
Culture- may show similar organism found in swabs from anal verge of victim

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 428.

questions.text: Whose permission is needed for a medically assisted termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Wife

The criteria for consent to be taken in MTP is 
  • Minimum age – 18 years
  • If minor – guardian consent
  • Husband’s consent not needed

According to MTP amendment act 2021
  1. Indications
    • Therapeutic – risk to mother’s life 
    • Eugenic – any risk of severe physical deformity to the foetus 
    • Social – contraceptive failure
    • Humanitarian – pregnancy due to rape
  2. MTP act with respect to duration of pregnancy 
    • <20 weeks – all cases
    • >20 weeks – No MTP except in cases of 
      • Rape
      • Minor
      • Foetal anomalies
      • Mentally ill 
    • >24 weeks – substantial foetal anomalies (permission from medical board needed)
  3. Who can do MTP
    • Registered medical practitioner with diploma/degree in Obg 
    • 1 year experience in Obg 
    • Assisted 25 cases of MTP (5 should be done independently)
  4. Maintenance of records for 5 years 
Reference: Pai SN, Chandra KS. Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act of India: Treading the Path between Practical and Ethical Reproductive Justice. Indian J Community Med. 2023 Jul-Aug;48(4):510-513. doi: 10.4103/ijcm.ijcm_540_22. Epub 2023 Jul 14. PMID: 37662131; PMCID: PMC10470576.

questions.text: The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' entails combining common home chemicals to produce:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: H2S and other poisonous gases.

The use of hydrogen sulfide as a means of committing suicide became a trend in Japan in 2007. In these cases, bath sulfur was mixed with toilet bowl cleaner to produce the gas.

Hydrogen sulfide forms a complex bond to the ferric moiety causing inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase (iron-containing protein), thereby arresting aerobic metabolism in an effect similar to cyanide toxicity.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 624.

Recommends treatment/ rehabilitation of drug users and punishment for drug peddlers

Farmers growing opium are permitted to grow and consume unlimited amounts of opium

questions.solution:

The law states rehabilitation for abusers and punishment for drug peddlers.
The following offences are included under the NDPS act:
