questions.text: A common technique for getting rid of some poisons and medications from the body is forced diuresis with urine that has been acidified or alkalinized. Which of the following medications' elimination is frequently aided by alkaline diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenobarbitone

Alkaline diuresis with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long-acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
As phenobarbitone is acidic drug forced alkaline diuresis helps in elimination of the drug.

Other management methods for phenobarbitone poisoning are:
  • Gastric lavage
  • Scandinavian method
  • Hemodialysis and Charcoal hemoperfusion.
  • CNS stimulants are to be avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 427.

questions.text: Educating kids to support a healthy lifestyle is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Primordial prevention

Educating kids to support a healthy lifestyle is a method to prevent introduction of risk factors in their life. It is a primordial form of prevention.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'Case-Control Study' is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: It is a prospective study

Case control study is a retrospective study.

The case control method has three distinct features :
a. both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
b. the study proceeds backwards from effect to cause; and
c. it uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an inference.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: With the exception of____all of the following are selection bias in case-control studies
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hawthorne bias
  • Hawthorne Bias: In case of cohort studies or long term cohort studies, when the person under observation shows change in behaviour e.g A smoker being studied for lung cancer risk stops smoking. This is known as Hawthorne bias.
  • Berksonian bias – Specific to hospital based case control studies. Ideally cases = controls but in hospitals the admission rates of controls is lesser and thus a bias emerges.
  • Volunteer bias – When participants are allowed to choose if they want to be a part of the sample. It leads to a sample that is not representative of the population as whole.
  • Neyman bias – In conditions with high rate of mortality, many diseases are missed due to the death of the cases.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about propagated epidemics is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  No secondary waves occur

Propagated epidemic shows secondary waves, which appear as successive peaks in a graph.
Person-to-person transmission occurs.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 73.

questions.text:
There are 100 youngsters living in a boarding house, and 15 of them have received the measles vaccine. 10 cases of measles occurred on the first of the month during an outbreak, and 35 cases on the eleventh. How common are measles secondary attacks?
1. \(35/85\times 100\)
2. \(35/75\times 100\)
3. \(35/100\times 100\)
4. \(45/85\times 100\)
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  \(35/75\times 100\)

The formula for secondary attack rate is


 
Total new cases = 35
Primary cases = 10
Total susceptible population = 100 – 15 (vaccinated)
Primary cases are excluded from both numerator and denominator.

SAR = 35/( 85 -10) x 100 = 35/75 x 100

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: What is the name of the combination of two variables described by a common third factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Indirect association

ASSOCIATIONS :-
  • It is defined as the concurrence of 2 variables more often than what is expected by chance.


 
  • SPURIOUS ASSOCIATION -  An observed association between a disease and suspected factor may not be real.
  • INDIRECT ASSOCIATION – It is a statistical association between a characteristic variable and disease due to the presence of another factor.
  • DIRECT ASSOCIATION –
    • ONE TO ONE CAUSAL RELATIONSHIP- Two variables are causally related if a change in one  variable is followed by a change in the other variable.
    • MULTIFACTORIAL RELATIONSHIP- When multiple factors are involved specially in case of non communicable diseases, a common event can be produced by each factors and that is also considered as a causal factor.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 95.

questions.text: Which sampling technique does the WHO most frequently employ to gauge immunisation coverage levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Cluster sampling

The Expanded Program on Immunisation (EPI) by WHO employs Cluster sampling to measure immunisation coverage levels.
210 children in 30 clusters with 7 children in each are taken.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 148.

choices.text: An individual having a cough of 2 weeks or more
Contacts of smear-positive TB patients having cough of 2 weeks or more
Suspected/confirmed extra-pulmonary TB having cough of any duration
HIV positive patient having cough of any duration

questions.text: Except for____, all of the following are considered "pulmonary TB suspects" according to RNTCP.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Contacts of smear-positive TB patients having cough of 2 weeks or more 


According to the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP),
  • a pulmonary TB suspect is an individual who has a cough of 2 weeks or more, and who has any of the following risk factors:
  • HIV infection
  • Recent contact with a smear-positive TB patient
  • Recent travel to a TB-endemic area
  • Immunocompromised state
 
  • Contacts of smear-positive TB patients are considered to be at high risk of TB, but they do not necessarily have a cough of 2 weeks or more.
  • Therefore, they are not considered to be pulmonary TB suspects according to the RNTCP.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210, 211, 212.

questions.text: All of the following pre-packaged kits are available for the care of genital ulcer disease under the National AIDS control programme, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Green
 
  • Under the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP) in India, pre-packaged kits are available for the care of Genital Ulcer Disease (GUD). These kits are color-coded for ease of identification and proper management.
  • The color-coded kits include:
  1. White Kit: Used for syndromic management of vaginal discharge.
  2.  Blue Kit:  Used for syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
  3.  Red Kit:  Used for syndromic management of GUD.
  4.  Yellow kit : Used to support people living with genital ulcer disease.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 501.

choices.text: Distance of safe water is greater than 1.6 km
Water is exposed to the risk of cholera
Water source has excess iron & heavy metals

questions.text: Which of the following is not definition of a problem village in the National Water Supply and Sanitation program ?
questions.solution:
• The National Water Supply and Sanitation Program (NWSSP) is a program launched by the Government of India to provide safe drinking water and sanitation facilities to rural communities.
  • The program identifies problem villages based on certain criteria, and provides assistance to improve their water supply and sanitation facilities.
  • The correct option, 4, is not a definition of a problem village in the NWSSP.
  • Guinea worm disease is caused by a parasitic worm called Dracunculus medinensis, which is transmitted through contaminated drinking water. However, the disease has been eradicated from India since 2000.
  • Therefore, the presence of Guinea worm infestation in a village is not a current problem in the context of the NWSSP.
  • On the other hand, the other three options are criteria used to identify problem villages in the NWSSP.
  • Option 1 states that if the distance of the safe water source is greater than 1.6 km, it is considered a problem village. Option 2 states that if the water source is exposed to the risk of cholera, it is considered a problem village.
  • Option 3 states that if the water source has excess iron and heavy metals, it is considered a problem village.
  • Therefore, based on the criteria used by the NWSSP to identify problem villages, option 4 is not a definition of a problem village, while options 1, 2, and 3 are.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 549.

questions.text: Which of the following national surveys is represented by the National Family Health Survey (NFHS) 2015–2016?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  4th
  • The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) is a large-scale, multi-round survey conducted in India to collect data on fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, nutrition, and other health-related topics.
  • The NFHS 2015-16 was conducted in 29 states and 7 union territories of India.
  • The NFHS 2015-16 is a valuable resource for understanding the health status of the Indian population and for planning and implementing health programs during those years.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 971.

questions.text: Except for________, all of the following are dimensions for gender empowerment measures.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Decent Standard of Living
 
  • Gender empowerment measures serve as vital tools to advance gender equality. They aid progress tracking, highlight improvement gaps, and inform policy and program development for gender parity.
  • The four dimensions of gender empowerment measures are:
  1. Political Participation and Decision-making:  women's involvement in politics and decision-making across different levels, local to national.
  2. Economic Participation and Decision-making: Gauges women's engagement in the economy and their authority in economic choices.
  3. Control over Economic Resources: Assesses women's dominance over economic assets like land, property, and income.
  4. Time Allocation: Evaluates women's allocation of time to unpaid responsibilities like caregiving.
  • Decent Standard of Living is not a dimension of gender empowerment measures. It is a measure of poverty, and it does not specifically address gender inequality.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 20.

questions.text: What is the UJJAWALA scheme about?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Child trafficking

The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 670.

questions.text: What does the WHO consider to be blindness?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO's definition, blindness is defined as having a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.
  • This means that a person who is blind can only see at less 3 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 456.

questions.text: If the water's Level of Hardness is 50–150 mg/L, how would you categorise it?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Moderately hard water.
 
  • Water hardness is determined by the concentration of calcium and magnesium ions in water.
  • A water hardness level of 50-150 mg/L is considered to be in the range of moderately hard water.
  • Moderately hard water may have some hardness effects, such as scaling in pipes and reduced soap lathering, but it is generally suitable for most domestic purposes.


There are two types of hardness of water:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 853, 854.

questions.text: About the mosquito Anopheles, all of the following are true, except:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1. "Eggs have no floats". 
1. Eggs have no floats - This statement is incorrect. Anopheles mosquito eggs have floats, which help them to float on the water surface. The floats are made up of a gelatinous material and are attached to the sides of the egg. These floats enable the eggs to survive in water bodies such as ponds, lakes, and puddles.
2. Larvae rest parallel to water surface - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito larvae rest parallel to the water surface. They breathe through a tube called a siphon, which they use to obtain air from the surface of the water.
3. Rudimentary siphon tube - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito larvae have a rudimentary siphon tube, which they use to obtain air from the surface of the water.
4. Spotted wings - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito wings have spots. The spots are a characteristic feature of the mosquito and can be used to identify the species. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 895.

questions.text: What kind of mosquito is referred to as the "tiger mosquito"?
questions.solution:
The Aedes mosquito, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is commonly known as the "tiger mosquito" due to the distinct black and white striped pattern on its body and legs, resembling a tiger's stripes.
  • These mosquitoes are vectors for several diseases, including dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  • Aedes aegypti is more common in urban areas and is a primary vector for dengue fever.
  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is more adaptable to different environments and can spread the same diseases as Aedes aegypti.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 897.

questions.text: What is a sterilising technique called incineration used for?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Human anatomical waste.
 
  • In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. 
  • This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. 
  • It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 916.

questions.text: Among the following, which is a live vaccine?
questions.solution:
Live attenuated vaccines-
  • Oral Sabin polio vaccine,
  • MRV Vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella, and Varicella),
  • Nasal influenza vaccine,
  • Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccine,
  • Varicella vaccine,

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: A vaccine is useable, in accordance with the Vaccine Vial Monitor, if:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Outer Circle Dark; Inner Square Light
 
  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 122.

questions.text: Which of the following strains is contained in the quadrivalent HPV vaccine?
questions.solution:
Quadrivalent HPV Vaccine contains strains 6,11,16,18.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 441.

questions.text: The period of quarantine for asymptomatic contacts of a cholera patient should be:
questions.solution:
The period of quarantine for asymptomatic contacts of a cholera patient is typically 5 days.
  • This period is chosen based on the incubation period of the cholera bacterium, Vibrio cholerae, which is usually between 2 to 5 days.
  • Quarantining contacts for 5 days helps ensure that if they were exposed and became infected, they would show symptoms within this time frame, thus preventing further spread of the disease.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 273.

questions.text: What among the following has nothing to do with Durkheim?
questions.solution:
Emile Durkheim is most known for his theories regarding "functionalism, division of labor, solidarity, and anomie".
  • He theorized that individual behavior is not only influenced by internal factors but also by external societal factors.
  • He is most well known as the author of On the "Division of Social Labor, The Rules of Sociological Method, Suicide, and The Elementary Forms of Religious Life".

Functionalism, in social sciences, is theory based on the premise that all aspects of a society—institutions, roles, norms, etc. —serve a purpose and that all are indispensable for the long-term survival of the society.
Emile Durkheim's theory of suicide defined anomic suicide as resulting from a lack of societal rules and norms. This happens during great social or economic change when people struggle to adjust. They feel overwhelmed and hopeless.


Online reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Durkheim

questions.text: When is World Health Day observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 7th April


Other options




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 1026.

questions.text: Which one of the following anemias has a raised MCV and normal MCHC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency
 
  • Anemia refers to a decrease in the number of red blood cells or a decrease in hemoglobin levels, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) is a measure of the average size of red blood cells.
  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency anemias are macrocytic anemias, characterized by an increased MCV (> 100 fL).
  • In these anemias, the red blood cells are larger than normal, but the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) remains within the normal range.
  • Other causes of macrocytic anemia, such as alcoholism and certain medications, can also be associated with an increased MCV.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: Which of the following anemias causes is linked to hypoplastic marrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fanconi's anemia
 
  • Fanconi's anemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by bone marrow failure, congenital abnormalities, and an increased risk of developing malignancies.
  • It is caused by mutations in genes involved in DNA repair mechanisms, leading to genomic instability.
  • The bone marrow in Fanconi's anemia patients may show hypoplasia or aplasia, meaning a decrease or absence of normal cellularity.
  • This bone marrow failure results in reduced production of all blood cell lineages, leading to pancytopenia.
  • Other features of Fanconi's anemia include physical abnormalities, such as skeletal malformations and characteristic facial features.
  • Other options - Primary Myelofibrosis has a proliferative and fibrotic phase, so hypercellular marrow is possible
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 314.

questions.text: Which of the following myeloproliferative illnesses is least likely to be linked to massive splenomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ET
 
  • Essential Thrombocythemia is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an elevated platelet count in the absence of secondary causes.
  • While splenomegaly can occur in ET, it is typically modest and not massive compared to other myeloproliferative disorders.
  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), PV and Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF) are myeloproliferative disorders that commonly present with massive splenomegaly.
  • In ET, the predominant feature is thrombocytosis, which can lead to an increased risk of thrombotic and hemorrhagic complications.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 625.

questions.text: Except for______,  all of the following are linked to secondary hemochromatosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
 
  • Secondary hemochromatosis refers to iron overload resulting from chronic transfusions or increased iron absorption.
  • Thalassemia Major, Sideroblastic Anemia, and Hereditary Spherocytosis can lead to secondary hemochromatosis due to chronic ineffective erythropoiesis, which causes increased iron absorption from the gut and subsequent iron overload.
  • In contrast, Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is not directly associated with secondary hemochromatosis as it is primarily characterized by complement-mediated hemolysis rather than chronic erythropoiesis and iron overload. Moreover, blood transfusion is not required in PNH so it has less chances of developing secondary hemochromatosis. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 848.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of multiple myeloma is least common?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hyperviscosity syndrome 
 
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is an unregulated proliferation of plasma cells.
  • The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity, leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. 
  • Common symptoms include bone pain due to bone involvement and lytic lesions.
  • Anemia is a frequent feature, and it can be normocytic (normal-sized red blood cells) and normochromic (normal hemoglobin content).
  • Multiple myeloma compromises the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to bacterial infections.
  • Hyperviscosity syndrome is a rare complication, characterized by increased blood viscosity due to high levels of abnormal proteins.
  • Hyperviscosity is more common with Walderstorm macroglobulinemia. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 869-871.

choices.text: Increased fibrinogen, increased antithrombin III, increased thrombin-antithrombin III complexes
Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III
Increased FDP, prolonged PT, decreased thrombin-antithrombin complexes

questions.text: The observation made in DIC is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced Platelets 
 
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications.
  • These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, and oozing from venipuncture sites. 
  • Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smears. 
 
  • Deranged clotting parameters are seen and fibrin degradation products such as D-dimers are elevated
  • Fibrin degradation products (FDP) are produced as a result of fibrinolysis (the breakdown of blood clots) and are increased in DIC.
  • The prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged in DIC due to the depletion of clotting factors, leading to impaired blood clotting.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 915-917.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia (Platelet count 50,000) and fragmented RBCs in a peripheral smear are symptoms of pregnancy in a 25-year-old woman. Which of the following differential diagnoses is least likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Evan's syndrome 
 
  • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) in a peripheral smear can occur in various medical conditions, including certain pregnancy-related complications.
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP), Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC), and HELLP syndrome are conditions that can cause thrombocytopenia and the presence of fragmented RBCs.
  • Evan's syndrome, although a condition with autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, is less likely to be the cause in this case.




Algorithm for Thrombocytopenia:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 905, 907.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best marker to look for in athletes with acute STEMI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Troponin T/I
 
  • Troponin T and Troponin I are cardiac-specific biomarkers that are released into the bloodstream when there is damage to the heart muscle, such as in acute STEMI.
  • They are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury, and their levels rise within a few hours after the onset of a heart attack.
  • Troponin T/I levels are widely used in clinical practice to diagnose acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and to assess its severity in athletes and non-athletes alike.
  • CK levels, CRP and LDH may be falsely elevated in professional athletes due to skeletal muscle damage that occurs. So, it can't be used as a marker for myocardial injury.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1116, 1184

questions.text: The initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic Pulmonary edema involves all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Digoxin
 
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: Accumulation of fluid in the lungs due to heart failure.
  • The initial treatment aims to relieve the acute symptoms and improve the patient's condition rapidly.
  • Digoxin is not typically used in the initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to its slower onset of action.
Management of Acute Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1942, 1943, 1950.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the lowest likelihood of being linked to infectious endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Small ASD
 
  • Infective endocarditis: Infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves, usually caused by bacteria or fungi.
  • It is most commonly associated with abnormalities that cause turbulent blood flow or damage to the endocardium, which can provide a favorable environment for bacterial attachment and colonization.
  • The risk of infective endocarditis is relatively lower for small ASDs compared to larger defects or conditions involving heart valves.
  • As the gradient is less in ASD thus turbulence doesn't take place and thus Infective Endocarditis doesn't usually happen. 
  • Other conditions like small ventricular septal defects (VSDs), mild mitral regurgitation (MR), and mild mitral stenosis (MS) may still present some risk, depending on their severity and structural abnormalities.


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1486.

questions.text: Which medication has been associated with a rise in cardiac mortality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rofecoxib
 
  • Rofecoxib has been associated with a rise in cardiac mortality.
  • Rofecoxib is a NSAID that was used for the treatment of pain and inflammation.
  • However, rofecoxib was withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, including an increased risk of heart attacks and strokes.
  • Several studies found an elevated risk of cardiovascular events, including cardiac mortality, among patients taking rofecoxib.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 222.

questions.text: After subclavian vein cannulation, a patient complains of abrupt onset of dyspnea. Upon examination, the chest is hyper resonant on one side, yet there are no breath sounds. The following is the root issue:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Iatrogenic Pneumothorax
 
  • The root issue in this case is likely an iatrogenic pneumothorax.
  • Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse.
  • Subclavian vein cannulation is a procedure that carries a risk of inadvertently puncturing the lung, resulting in the introduction of air into the pleural space.
  • The sudden onset of dyspnea, hyperresonance on one side of the chest, and absence of breath sounds are all indicative of a pneumothorax.
  • Prompt recognition and management of a pneumothorax are crucial to prevent further complications and ensure the patient's respiratory stability.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 407.

choices.text: Contralateral mediastinal nodes are a contraindication to surgical resection
Single Agent Chemotherapy is preferred for patients> 70 years with advanced disease
Squamous Cell Carcinoma is the most common NSCCL amongst Asian population
Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology

questions.text: The following descriptions of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCCL) are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology 
 
  • Gefitinib is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of NSCLC with specific EGFR mutations.
  • It has shown significant efficacy in patients with EGFR mutations, particularly in those with exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.
  • EGFR mutations are more common in Asian populations and in non-smokers or light smokers and have adenocarcinoma histology, but it is not limited to female smokers.
  • Gefitinib is more effective in patients with EGFR mutations, regardless of gender or smoking history.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 595, 600, 606, 607.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man arrives with hypertension and widespread edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm).He has anti-hepatitis C antibodies and his serum complement levels have dropped. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cryoglobulinemia

Clinical features of chronic hepatitis C are similar to those described above for chronic hepatitis B. Generally, fatigue is the most common symptom; jaundice is rare. Immune complex–mediated extrahepatic complications of chronic hepatitis C are less common than in chronic hepatitis B (despite the fact that assays for immune complexes are often positive in patients with chronic hepatitis C), with the exception of essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is linked to cutaneous vasculitis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis as well as lymphoproliferative disorders such as B-cell lymphoma and unexplained monoclonal gammopathy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman arrives with hypertension, skin ulceration, and generalized edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm). She tests positive for hepatitis C and has lower serum complement levels. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
 
  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is strongly associated with hepatitis C.
  • Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins (immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C) in the serum.
  • Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis (skin ulcers, purpura), arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.
  • The presence of a measurable amount of cryoglobulin (cryocrit) with low C4 complement levels is the laboratory hallmark of cryoglobulinemia.
  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can also cause glomerulonephritis, but they are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia or hepatitis C infection


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH<5
Associated with increased risk of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Associated with Hyperkalemia
 
  • RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc.
  • The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 
  • Type I RTA is associated with an increased risk of urinary stones due to the precipitation of certain minerals in the urine .The increased risk of urinary stones is related to the alkalinization of urine.
  • Treatment for Type I RTA involves alkali replacement as bicarbonate to help correct the metabolic acidosis

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 351 .

questions.text: A patient who was given a bronchiectasis diagnosis five years ago appears with proteinuria and edema on the legs. His kidneys will most likely reveal one of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amyloid Nephropathy
 
  • Amyloid nephropathy: Kidney damage and dysfunction caused by amyloid protein deposition..
  • It can present with proteinuria and edema due to impaired kidney function and fluid retention.
  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition, and in some cases, it can be associated with systemic amyloidosis, leading to amyloid deposition in various organs, including the kidneys.
Other options:
  • Minimal change disease (MCD): Glomerulonephritis with minimal glomerular changes, often in young individuals with allergies.
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): Severe form of glomerulonephritis, leads to rapid kidney failure. Associated with infections, autoimmune diseases, and medications.
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis: Type of RPGN with crescent-shaped structures in glomeruli, causing kidney damage.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 878, 2345.

choices.text: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis

questions.text: What is the least accurate statement concerning hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis 
 
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) : Triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
  • The most common cause of HUS is infection with Shiga toxin-producing E.coli (STEC), often following ingestion of contaminated food, particularly undercooked ground beef or raw vegetables.
  • Shiga toxin from STEC damages blood vessel endothelial cells, causing microthrombi and organ damage, especially in the kidneys (HUS pathogenesis).
Other options:
  • A. HUS is commonly associated with a preceding infection, often hemorrhagic colitis caused by STEC.
  • B. HUS is often self-limited, meaning it tends to resolve on its own in many cases, especially in children. However, some cases can be severe and require medical intervention.
  • C. Fever is usually mild or absent in HUS, and it is not a prominent symptom.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2285, 2286, 2348.

questions.text: Which medication is prescribed for constipating-related irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lubiprostone

Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Other options:
 
  • Cholestyramine resin – used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS.
  • Alosetron, a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS relieves pain and abdominal discomfort. It causes constipation in IBS patients with diarrhea alternating with constipation.
  • Rifaximin is a RNA synthesis inhibitor approved for use in diarrhea-predominant IBS.

IBS management:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2496.

questions.text: An individual receiving ketoconazole treatment for a fungus develops gastroesophageal reflux illness (GERD). Which medication from the list below shouldn't be given to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Cisapride
 
  • Cisapride is a prokinetic agent. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism aided by weak 5-HT3 antagonism.
  • It enhances gastrointestinal motility and is often used to treat conditions like GERD and gastroparesis.
  • However, cisapride has a potential interaction with ketoconazole, which can lead to an increased risk of life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias (specifically, QT prolongation).
  • Due to this risk, cisapride should not be given to individuals who are taking ketoconazole or other medications that can prolong the QT interval.
  • Metoclopromide and Domperidone may also cause QTc prolongation but its frequency and severity is much less Cisapride

Drugs causing QT prolongation: 





Prokinetics :





Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 715, 716.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who had previously experienced protracted fever and discomfort in her abdomen was found to have splenomegaly and leukopenia. She developed an acute abdominal incident throughout the course of the illness and passed away. What is the most likely outcome of the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Longitudinal ulcers
 
  • The given clinical scenario suggests a case of Typhoid disease
  • Longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid 
  • Ulcer may perforated -> peritonitis and finally may lead to death 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies occurs most frequently in short bowel syndrome with ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamin)
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.
  • Absorption of Fat soluble vitamins are also impaired




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: The most typical vitamin deficiency associated with short bowel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: A man comes in with a history of hematemesis involving 500 ml of blood. Spleen is detectable on inspection 5 cm below the left costal border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Portal Hypertension
 
  • Portal hypertension: Increased pressure in the portal vein, which carries blood from the intestines to the liver.
  • When portal hypertension is present, it can lead to the development of varices (dilated veins) in the esophagus and stomach, which are prone to bleeding.
  • Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is a common symptom in patients with portal hypertension and ruptured esophageal or gastric varices.
  • The detectable spleen below the left costal border is known as splenomegaly and is often associated with portal hypertension.

Causes of portal HTN :



Varices:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2629.

questions.text: What among the following is a "Small Vessel Vasculitis"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Microscopic polyangiitis
 
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis is a systemic vasculitis affecting small blood vessels, including arterioles, capillaries, and venules.
  • It is characterized by necrotizing inflammation of vessel walls, without granulomatous inflammation.
  • The term "microscopic" refers to the involvement of small vessels, which can be visualized microscopically.
  • Other forms of small vessel vasculitis include Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) and Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), which involve granulomatous inflammation.
Vasculitis Memorizing Trick: -
Large vessel- GT road is the largest road- Giant cell arteritis and Takayasu arteritis
Medium Vessel- PK- PAN and Kawasaki 
Rest are small vessel vasculitis

VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Except for ________, all of the following conditions are linked to type 1 cryoglobulinemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor
 
  • Type 1 cryoglobulinemia is specifically linked to monoclonal gammopathies, including monoclonal IgM paraprotein (Option B).
  • Hyperviscosity (Option A) can occur due to increased levels of cryoglobulins in the blood, leading to blood flow issues.
  • In type 1 cryoglobulinemia, complement levels (Option C) are typically normal, unlike in type 2 and type 3 cryoglobulinemia, where complement levels are reduced.
  • Rheumatoid factor is an antibody that is produced in people with rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is not typically associated with type 1 cryoglobulinemia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2340,2341 .

choices.text: Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following is true for fibromyalgia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus 
 
  • Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. 
  • Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.
  • Anti-polymer antibody may be seen in 50% of patients. 
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) studies done on fibromyalgia patients show hypoperfusion of the thalamus.
Other options:
 
  • Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in non-REM sleep, not REM sleep.
  • Cortisol levels in fibromyalgia patients are typically within the normal range.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2868-2870.

questions.text: The emergence of hyperthyroidism after supplementary iodine treatment to people with endemic iodine deficient goitre is termed as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Jod-Basedow effect
 
  • The Jod-Basedow effect is due to overactivation of the thyroid gland or autonomous nodules within the gland after iodine repletion without adequate feedback control from the pituitary gland.
  • This phenomenon does not occur in individuals with normal thyroid gland.
  • In iodine-deficient areas, the thyroid gland cannot produce enough hormones due to the lack of iodine. When excess iodine is introduced suddenly, it causes the thyroid to produce and release more hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism.

Other options:
 
  • Wolff-Chaikoff effect: Opposite phenomenon, where a transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis occurs in response to a large amount of iodine exposure.
  • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Hyperthyroidism caused by the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone.
  •  De Quervain's thyroiditis: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, leading to transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2938, 2945.

questions.text: Which option best describes the lowest detection limit for third generation TSH assays?
questions.solution:
Serum TSH is the initial screening test for primary thyroid dysfunction. TSH is a glycoprotein hormone produced by the pituitary gland. It stimulates the thyroid gland to secrete thyroid hormones, which regulate tissue metabolism.

TSH assays are named historically by “generation”; third generation assays are widely used and have a detection limit of 0.01 mIU/L, as compared to first (1 mIU/L) and second generation assays (0.1–0.2 mIU/L).



Reference: Papaleontiou, Maria, and Anne R Cappola. “Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone in the Evaluation of Subclinical Hypothyroidism.” JAMA vol. 316,15 (2016): 1592-1593. doi:10.1001/jama.2016.9534. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5450818/

questions.text: Which of the following has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
• Gynecomastia is a medical condition characterized by the enlargement of male breast tissue. It is caused by an imbalance in the hormones estrogen and testosterone.
  • The condition is often associated with increased levels of estrogen or decreased levels of testosterone in males. Out of the given options, prolactinoma has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.
  • Prolactinoma is a noncancerous tumor of the pituitary gland that produces high levels of prolactin hormone. Prolactin stimulates milk production in females and can cause breast enlargement and lactation in males. However, the likelihood of prolactinoma causing gynecomastia is lower compared to the other options.
  • Adrenal tumors can produce excess estrogen or androgen hormones, leading to gynecomastia.
  • hCG-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia as they stimulate the production of estrogen. Estrogen-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia directly by increasing estrogen levels in the body.
 
  • Therefore, based on the above information, option 1, which is prolactinoma, has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909, 2910, 2967.

questions.text: Except for____, all of the following agents may be used to treat Chronic Hypocalcemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Etidronate
 
  • Etidronate is not used for the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate primarily used to treat hypercalcemia.
  • The main goal in managing hypoparathyroidism is to restore the balance of calcium and phosphate in the body.

Other options:
 
  • The mainstay of treatment involves calcium and vitamin D supplements.
  • Thiazide diuretics can be prescribed along with a low-sodium diet to enhance urinary calcium reabsorption.
  • Other underlying conditions contributing to hypocalcemia should also be addressed during the management process.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 2936.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who has a history of falling frequently and having more difficult walking presents to the outpatient  department. A physical examination indicates nystagmus and an ataxic gait. While the plantar response was "Extensor," it was noticed that all deep tendon reflexes were absent. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Friedreich's Ataxia
 
  • Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia and is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin.
  • This disorder typically occurs in individuals less than 25 years of age.
Clinical features of Friedreich's ataxia include:
  • dysarthria
  • progressive staggering gait
  • frequent falls
  • nystagmus
  • titubation (nodding head and body movements).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3425, 3426.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with complaints of discomfort, weariness, and weakness in both lower limbs arrives at the outpatient clinic. She discusses her childhood experience with paralysis involving both lower limbs, from which she made a good functional recovery. The most likely suspected diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Post-Polio syndrome

Post-Polio Syndrome:
 
  • After an interval of 30-40 years, around 30-40% of persons who survived paralytic poliomyelitis in childhood, experience muscle pain and exacerbation of existing weakness or development of new weakness or paralysis. It is known as post polio syndrome.
 
  • It has been reported only in persons who were infected in the era of wild-type poliovirus circulation.

Risk factors for post polio syndrome include:
 
  • Permanent impairment after recovery from acute polio infection
  • Increasing length of time from acute polio infection
  • Female sex



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1603.

questions.text: A patient with acute paraplegia caused by a "T3 level" thoracic cord injury was found to have a blood pressure reading of 210/120. What should the initial management be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Nifedipine
 
  • Autonomic dysreflexia is a condition that emerges when the spinal cord is injured above the T6 level. 
  • The blood pressure of the patient suddenly rises in response to stimuli like bladder or bowel distension that originates below the level of injury. 
  • It is usually accompanied by a severe headache, bradycardia, and facial flushing, along with pallor, cold skin, and sweating in the lower part of the body. 
 
  • It is treated with vasodilators to manage acute BP elevation. 
  • Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that helps to lower blood pressure by relaxing and dilating blood vessels.
  • Clonidine is prophylactically used to reduce hypertension resulting from bladder stimulation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3433.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel

questions.text: A reducible hernia beneath the inguinal ligament is discovered in an asymptomatic healthy patient. Which of the following management strategies should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Surgical repair on the next elective list
 
  • In an asymptomatic healthy patient with a reducible hernia beneath the inguinal ligament, surgical repair on the next elective list is the recommended management strategy.
  • Surgical repair aims to reinforce the weakened area and prevent the hernia from becoming incarcerated or strangulated in the future.
  • Elective repair allows for proper planning and preparation, minimizing the risk of complications and ensuring optimal outcomes.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1062.

questions.text: What nerve is most susceptible to damage during laparoscopic hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4. Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in laparoscopic hernia repair. Ilioinguinal is most common nerve injured during open hernia repair. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1070.

questions.text: All of the following surround the "Triangle of Doom," except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Inguinal ligament

* The triangle of doom:


Fig: The triangle of doom

* Contents of the Space:
  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1605.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Stoppa operation
 
  • The open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is known as the Stoppa operation.
  • It involves creating a pre-peritoneal space and placing a large mesh in this space to provide support and reinforcement to the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The mesh is positioned behind the transversalis fascia, covering the potential spaces where hernias can occur.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1125.

questions.text: The Ankle Branchial Pressure Index indicating Imminent Necrosis is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: <0.3 
 
  • The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is used to assess blood flow and perfusion in the lower extremities.
  • ABPI compares the BP in the ankle to the BP in the arm.
  • An ABPI <0.3 suggests severe arterial disease and a critical reduction in blood flow to the legs.
  • At this level, there is a high risk of tissue damage and the development of necrosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1003.

questions.text: What is the most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Popliteal
 
  • The most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms is: Popliteal > Femoral > Axillary > Subclavian
  • Among the options provided, the most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms is the popliteal artery (located behind the knee).
  • Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms account for more than 90% of peripheral aneurysms, with popliteal artery aneurysms being the most common
  • Popliteal artery Aneurysms can lead to symptoms such as a pulsatile mass, pain, or limb ischemia.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1003.

questions.text: Cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp are most commonly caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Superficial temporal artery
 
  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling over the scalp or face that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections in the scalp and extremities.
  • They are usually congenital. 
  • However, in some cases, they may be traumatic.
  • The superficial temporal artery is commonly involved in cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 209.

questions.text: The most prevalent DVT manifestation is:
questions.solution:
Most common presentation of DVT is pain and swelling.

Charley horse cramp - A sudden, involuntary contraction of one or more muscles (cramp), often in the legs.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 323.

choices.text: Typically presents between postoperative day 3 and day 5
Suture length should be 4 times of wound length
High incidence if Catgut is used for closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "Burst Abdomen" is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Typically presents between postoperative day 3 and day 5
 
  • Burst abdomen is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration.
  • It commonly occurs within the first few days after surgery, usually between postoperative day 5 and day 8.
  • Other factors such as wound tension, inadequate suturing technique, or compromised tissue healing can contribute to the development of Burst Abdomen.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 732.

questions.text: What is most frequently related with the obturator sign in acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pelvic Appendix
 
  • The obturator sign is a clinical finding in which the patient experiences pain upon internal rotation of the flexed right hip. It is suggestive of inflammation in the region of the obturator muscle.
  • The pelvic appendix, which is located in the pelvis near the obturator muscle, is most frequently associated with the obturator sign.
  • The proximity of the pelvic appendix to the obturator muscle can cause irritation and inflammation, leading to the positive obturator sign.
* Signs seen in acute appendicitis:



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1332.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of action for a 0.5 mm carcinoid tumour at the appendix's tip?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Appendectomy
 
  • The recommended course of action for a 0.5 mm carcinoid tumor at the tip of the appendix is appendectomy.
  • The small size of the tumor and its location at the tip of the appendix suggest a low risk of metastasis or invasion into surrounding tissues.
  • Therefore, a less extensive procedure such as appendectomy is sufficient to remove the tumor and prevent any potential complications. 
Other options:
  • Right hemicolectomy, colectomy, and hepatic wedge resection are more extensive procedures and are typically reserved for larger or more advanced tumors that have invaded nearby structures or have a higher risk of metastasis.
Guideline for Appendicular Carcinoid- 
  • Tumor < 2 cm and >2cm from base- Appendectomy
  • Tumor>2cm and <2cm from base- Right Hemicolectomy 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1344.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Kasai procedure
 
  • The preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia is the Kasai procedure.
  • The Kasai procedure (Hepatoportoenterostomy) involves creating a surgical connection between the liver and the small intestine to bypass the obstructed bile ducts.
  • This procedure aims to restore bile flow and prevent further damage to the liver.
  • Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.
* Types of Biliary Atresia: 



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: What is the cut-off for severe acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: APACHE II Score > 8

The cut-off for severe acute pancreatitis is an APACHE II score greater than 8.
  • The APACHE II (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II) score is a widely used scoring system to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis.
  • It takes into account several physiological parameters such as vital signs, laboratory values, and age to determine the severity of the condition.
  • A score greater than 8 indicates a higher likelihood of severe pancreatitis, which is associated with increased morbidity and mortality.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: A midline painful fluctuant lump between the gluteal folds is found in a young guy. A rectal examination is painless. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pilonidal abscess
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for a midline painful fluctuant lump between the gluteal folds in a young guy is a pilonidal abscess.
  • Pilonidal abscess is a common condition characterized by the formation of an abscess or cyst in the natal cleft (the area between the buttocks).
  • It typically occurs in young individuals and is more common in males.
  • The abscess is often painful and may be associated with redness, swelling, and fluctuance.
  • Unlike perianal and perirectal abscesses, which are usually located near the anus, a pilonidal abscess is typically found in the midline between the gluteal folds.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1423.

questions.text: 1. Except for_______  , all of the following bind the gastrinoma triangle.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein

Except for the spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein (option D), all of the following structures bind the gastrinoma triangle.
  • The gastrinoma triangle is an anatomical region in the upper abdomen that is commonly associated with the presence of gastrinomas, tumors that produce excessive amounts of gastrin.
  • Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro's triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:
  • Cystic duct
  • Junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum

questions.text: A melanoma with a depth of 0.5 mm should have the following recommended margin for a wide local incision:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 1 cm
 
  • A melanoma with a depth of 0.5 mm requires a wide local incision.
  • The recommended margin for a wide local incision in this case is 1 cm.
  • The margin refers to the distance of healthy tissue that should be removed along with the melanoma to ensure complete excision and reduce the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: Starting at what age do new mammogram screening recommendations suggest mammography should be routinely provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 40 years
 
  • New mammogram screening recommendations suggest routine mammography should be provided starting at the age of 40 years.
  • A mammography is a screening tool used for the early detection of breast cancer.
  • However, in certain cases, ultrasound (USG) can be used before the age of 40 for breast evaluation.
  • USG is particularly useful in younger women with specific risk factors or clinical indications.
* Advantages of USG over Mammography:
  • Preferred in pregnant, lactating, and young women with dense breast tissue
  • Differentiation between solid and cystic breast lesions
  • Detection of abnormal axillary lymph nodes
  • Assists in guided breast biopsy procedures
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of for Zuska's Disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Antibiotics, Incision and Drainage

Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. 
  • Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition
  • It is managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage if necessary
  • The initial management usually involves a combination of antibiotics to treat the underlying infection and surgical intervention in the form of incision and drainage of the abscess.

Fig: Zuska's Disease

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 550.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is recommended for treating cystosarcoma phyllodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Wide local excision
 
  • The recommended approach for treating cystosarcoma phyllodes is a wide local incision.
  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes (phyllodes tumour) is a rare breast tumor that has both benign and malignant characteristics.
  • A wide local excision involves removing the tumor along with a margin of normal surrounding tissue to ensure complete removal.
  • This approach allows for preservation of breast tissue and avoids more extensive procedures like mastectomy.




Fig: Malignant phyllodes tumor (cystosarcomaphyllodes)

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: What is most likely to be the source of tingling and numbness across the posteromedial portion of the upper arm following a modified radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intercostobrachial nerve
 
The given case scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic injury to the intercostobrachial nerve.
  • It is a branch of the 2nd intercostal nerve.
  • It is the lateral cutaneous branch of the 2nd intercostal nerve and supplies the skin of the axilla and upper part of the medial aspect of the arm. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text: Which of the following intrauterine contraceptives does not require replacement even after being used for three to five years?

Correct option is 3: CuT 380A.

  • The IUD's effectiveness is maintained for several years due to the continuous release of copper, which interferes with sperm mobility and fertilization.
  • CuT 380A is an effective and convenient contraceptive option for women who desire long-term protection from pregnancy without frequent replacements.

questions.text: At term, a female G3P1A1 is allowed into the delivery room. Cervical dilation of 4 cm, membranes intact, and head 3/5 per abdomen palpable. When the examination is repeated 4 hours later, the cervix is still 4 cm dilated, the station is unaltered, and the cervicograph is located on the right side of the action line. Correct option: 3. The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required. This is because the plotting is located on the right side of the action line which necessitates some intervention.

Other options:

choices.text: First twin has higher risk of birth asphyxia
Second twin has higher risk of Hyaline Membrane disease
First twin has higher risk of mortality
Second twin has higher risk of Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following statements about twin vaginal preterm delivery is correct?
questions.solution:
• Twin vaginal preterm delivery refers to the delivery of two babies before the completion of 37 weeks of gestation through the vaginal route. In such cases, the second twin has a higher risk of developing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease (HMD) than the first twin.
  • This is because during a vaginal delivery, the first twin compresses the placenta and umbilical cord, which can cause a decrease in blood flow and oxygen supply to the second twin.
  • As a result, the second twin may develop respiratory distress syndrome due to inadequate surfactant production, which is essential for lung function.
  • On the other hand, the first twin has a higher risk of birth asphyxia due to the prolonged labor, which can cause a decrease in blood flow and oxygen supply to the baby.
  • However, the risk of mortality is not necessarily higher in the first twin as compared to the second twin. Similarly, the risk of intracranial hemorrhage is not necessarily higher in the second twin as compared to the first twin.
  • Therefore, option 2 is correct, which states that the second twin has a higher risk of developing hyaline membrane disease.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 853, 854.

questions.text: What happens to the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
In preeclampsia, both GFR and renal plasma flow decrease by 30% to 40% compared with normal pregnancy of the same duration.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) rise appreciably. With preeclampsia, several reversible physiological changes ensue. Of clinical importance, renal perfusion and GFR are slightly reduced. Most of the decrement in GFR is from increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance.

End organ damage occurs in Pre-eclampsia. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 697.

questions.solution:

Option(2) is a correct statement - as seen in the above table - the risk of transmission varies from 15-25% with no breastfeeding and 20-35 % with breastfeeding but the majority i.e. 60-70% infants are not affected even without intervention. 

Option(3) is a correct statement. As seen in the above table- The maximum transmission occurs during labor and delivery(10-15%) and elective LSCS can reduce the same.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of breech presentation?
questions.solution:
At 28 weeks 25% breech presentation is seen but at time of delivery 3% breech is seen.

Causes of breech presentation
1. Prematurity ( at 30 wks. 25% breech )
2. Uterine abnormalities
3. Fetal factors prevent spontaneous version
4. Placenta previa
5. fibroids
6. Hydrocephaly
7. unknown

The following are the known factors responsible for breech presentation: 
  1. Prematurity: It is the most common cause of breech presentation.
  2. Factors preventing spontaneous version: (a) Breech with extended legs (b) Twins (c) Oligohydramnios (d) Congenital malformation of the uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus, (e) Short cord, relative or absolute, (f) Intrauterine death of the fetus.
  3. Favorable adaptation: (a) Hydrocephalus—big head can be well accommodated in the wide fundus, (b) Placenta previa, (c) Contracted pelvis, (d) Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta—minimizes the space of the fundus where the smaller head can be placed comfortably.
  4. Undue mobility of the fetus: (a) Hydramnios, (b) Multiparae with lax abdominal wall.
  5. Fetal abnormality: Trisomies 13, 18, 21, anencephaly and myotonic dystrophy due to alteration of fetal muscular tone and mobility.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: Which of the following occiput-posterior positions is the most common?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Right Occipito-posterior 
  • Right occipito-posterior is five times more common than the left occipito-posterior.
  • Dextrorotation of the uterus and the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left disfavor LOP position.
  • In a vertex presentation where the occiput is placed posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum, it is called an occiput-posterior position. When the occiput is placed over the right sacroiliac joint, the position is called right occipitoposterior (ROP), traditionally called third position of the vertex and when placed over the left sacroiliac joint, is called left occipitoposterior (LOP), traditionally called fourth position of the vertex.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 424.

questions.text: What is the most common procedure indicative of a posterior cleft?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Drainage of Pelvic Abscess

A posterior cleft refers to a disruption or defect in the rectovaginal septum, often as a result of infection or trauma.
The most common sign of a posterior cleft is the drainage of a pelvic abscess, especially when there is a localized infection that leads to the formation of an abscess in the pelvic region.

Pelvic abscess is a life-threatening collection of infected fluid in the pouch of Douglas, fallopian tube, ovary, or parametric tissue. Usually, a pelvic abscess occurs as a complication after operative procedures. It starts as pelvic cellulitis or hematoma spreads to parametrial tissue.
A pelvic abscess produces a fluctuating tender swelling in the POD, bulging into the posterior fornix.

TREATMENT of Pelvic Abscess: 
 
  • General: Systemic antibiotics should cover anaerobic as well as aerobic microorganisms (broad spectrum): Cefoxitin 1–2 g IV every 6–8 hours and gentamicin 2 mg/ kg IV per 24 hours and metronidazole 500 mg IV 8 hourly are started. Antibiotic regimen may have to be changed depending upon the sensitivity report.
  • Surgery: Posterior colpotomy is the definitive surgery to drain the pus through posterior fornix. The loculi should be broken with finger.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 143.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 341.

questions.text: What is softening of a lower uterine region on bimanual examination referred to as?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hegar's Sign
 

Hegar's sign is an indication of early pregnancy characterized by softening of the lower uterine segment (the area between the cervix and the body of the uterus) that can be felt during a bimanual examination.

Other options (Signs of Pregnancy):

  1. Chadwick Sign: Refers to a bluish discoloration of the cervix, vagina, and vulva due to increased blood flow, which can be an early sign of pregnancy.
  2. Osiander's Sign: Refers to the detection of pulsations in the lateral vaginal fornices
  3. Goodell's Sign: Refers to the softening of the cervix, often occurring early in pregnancy.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 23.

questions.text: What is the effect of twin gestation if division occurs on the seventh day?
questions.solution:
• Option 2, Diamniotic, monochorionic, is the correct answer if division of the zygote occurs on the seventh day after fertilization.
  • When a single zygote divides into two embryos, the resulting twins can either share a chorion (the outermost fetal membrane) and/or an amniotic sac (the innermost fetal membrane).
  • The chorion can either be shared (monochorionic) or separate (dichorionic), while the amniotic sac can either be shared (monoamniotic) or separate (diamniotic).
  • Division of the zygote on the seventh day results in two separate embryos that each have their own amniotic sac, but share a chorion. This is because the chorion starts to form on the fifth day after fertilization and is usually complete by the seventh day.
  • Therefore, the twins are diamniotic, meaning they each have their own amniotic sac, but monochorionic, meaning they share a chorion.
  • It is important to note that the timing of division is critical in determining the type of twinning that occurs. If division occurs earlier or later than the seventh day, different types of twinning can result, such as dichorionic, diamniotic twins if division occurs before the third day, or monochorionic, monoamniotic twins if division occurs after the eighth day.


Sustained/marked rise in Estrogen
Students should remember the division and corresponding days for twin gestation.



Reference- Williams Obstretics, 26th Edition, Page no: 839,840

questions.text: What does the phrase "couvelaire uterus" refer to?
questions.solution:
Uteroplacental apoplexy is a rare but nonfatal complication of severe forms of placental abruption. It occurs when vascular damage within the placenta causes hemorrhaging that progresses to and infiltrates the wall of the uterus. It is a syndrome that can only be diagnosed by direct visualization or biopsy (or both). It has gun powdered appearance. 
 
  • At the time of cesarean delivery, it is common to and widespread extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature and beneath the serosa. This phenomenon is named after Couvelaire, who in the early 1900s termed it as uteroplacental apoplexy.
  • These myometrial hemorrhages may incite uterine atony. Effusions of blood may collect beneath the tubal serosa, between the leaves of the broad ligaments, in the ovaries, or in the peritoneal cavity.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 753.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Arias Stella's reaction?

Arias-Stella reaction may be encountered during normal or ectopic pregnancy, in gestational trophoblastic disease, or in association with exogenous hormone administration.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: All Skin and Bone Appearance.
 
  • Kwashiorkor is a severe form of protein-energy malnutrition that primarily affects young children in areas with inadequate protein intake.
  • The characteristic features of Kwashiorkor include edema (swelling due to fluid retention), fatty liver, hair changes (flag sign), and skin lesions (flaky paint dermatosis).
 
  • Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake.
  • It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles.

  •  65%-70% at 2 mins
  •  70%-75% at 3 mins
  •  75%-80% at 4 mins
  •  80%-85% at the end of 5 minutes.
  •  85% – 95% between 5-10 mins
 These targets should be achieved by initiating resuscitation with a low oxygen concentration (21%O2 – 30%O2)  

 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 128

questions.text: Which vaccination among the following was discontinued due to a higher risk of intussusception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Rota Virus Vaccine
 
  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a risk of developing intussusception, usually within a week after the first or second dose.
  • Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a very minimal risk of intussusception.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 130.

questions.text: Which of the following specimen yields the maximum organism in a case of visceral leishmaniasis?
