questions.text: Which of the following will not produce conductive hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Endolymphatic Hydrops

Endolymphatic hydrops/ Meniere's produces sensorineural hearing loss not conductive hearing loss. It causes dilatation utricles and saccule leading to poor inner ear functioning.
Otosclerosis, Serous otitis media and suppurative otitis media are diseases of the middle ear thus leading to conductive hearing loss.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 111

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient who has an extremely painful external ear lesion and otorrhea that is not responding to antibiotics presents. The external ear shows signs of granulation-type tissue, and bone erosion and facial nerve palsy are also present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Malignant Otitis Externa

Malignant otitis externa aka Necrotising otitis externa is a severe invasive infection caused by pseudomonas and commonly affects immunocompromised elderly. It presents with necrosis, granulations and cranial nerve involvement of 7,9,10,11. It can invade and cause Skull base osteomyelitis through fissure of Santorini. IOC is Tc 99m scan.  Management includes ciprofloxacin/ 3rd gen cephalosporins and controlling sugars if diabetic.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 55

questions.text: From which of the following routes does a middle ear infection not spread to the brain?
questions.solution:

Middle ear infection doesn’t spread to brain via lymphatic spread
Routes for spread include Direct bony invasion, hematogenous, via oval/round window/ cochlear aqueduct, traumatic/surgical openings

choices.text: Better chance of acquiring normal or near normal verbal skills

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Tinnitus enhancement in patients with tinnitus prior to implantation 

Tinnitus does not enhance in patients with tinnitus prior to cochlear implantation.
Cochler implant functions as a replacement of organ of corti which then eventually stimulates cochlear nerve. Indications include- 1. Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss >70dB  2. No benefit from hearing aid after trial of at least 3 months 3. Pre-Lingual deafness/ Children who are born deaf.

questions.text: An older man appears with dysphagia, regurgitation, foul breath, and a cough. On inspection, there is evidence of bilateral lung crept. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Zenker's diverticulum

Zenker’s diverticulum arises from Killian’s triangle which is between the thyropharyngeus (supplied by Pharyngeal Plexus) and cricopharyngeus (supplied by RLN) part of the Inferior constrictor muscle. It is a false diverticulum (only mucosa and submucosa) and occurs commonly in the elderly. Neuromuscular incoordination during swallowing leads to herniation through Killian's dehiscence due to increased pressure. Dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation and aspiration are common presentations.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 310

questions.text: Which Salter-Harris type describes a fracture including the epiphysis, Diaphysis, and Metaphysis?

questions.text: Which of the following does not include The Unhappy Triad of O'Donoghue?
questions.solution:
• O'Donoghue unhappy triad or terrible triad often occurs in contact and non-contact sports, such as basketball, football, or rugby, when there is a lateral force applied to the knee while the foot is fixated on the ground.
  • This produces an abduction-external rotation mechanism of injury ("pivot shift" in non-contact sports).
  • It comprises three types of soft tissue injury that frequently tend to occur simultaneously in knee injuries. O'Donoghue described the injuries as:
  1. Anterior cruciate ligament tear
  2. Medial collateral ligament injury
  3. Medial meniscal tear 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 149

questions.text: Which of the following structures has additional synovial, intracapsular tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Long Biceps Tendon
 
  • The long biceps tendon is located in the shoulder joint, specifically in the intertubercular groove of the humerus.
  • It is part of the biceps brachii muscle, which has two tendons - the long head and the short head. The long head of the biceps tendon travels within the shoulder joint and has a synovial sheath that allows it to move smoothly and reduce friction during joint movement.
  • Inside the shoulder joint, the long biceps tendon has additional synovial, intracapsular tissue because of its sheath, which is not present in the other structures listed.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 917

questions.text: A patient with an upper lid chalazion that was recurring underwent a biopsy. What is the most likely histopathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Sebaceous cell carcinoma.
 
  • A chalazion is a benign, inflammatory condition characterized by a localized swelling in the eyelid caused by the obstruction of the meibomian glands.
  • A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).
  • A very small, soft, and recent chalazion only requires conservative management with hot compresses and topical antibiotic drops. Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1301.

questions.text: A nodule around the limbus with hyperemia of the surrounding tissue in the left eye is evident in a malnourished youngster from a low socioeconomic background, living in crowded and filthy environments. Additionally, axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy are noted in him. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis.
 
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an Inflammatory condition that affects the conjunctiva, characterized by the presence of nodules or small elevations around the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera) and hyperemia of the surrounding tissue.
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It is more common in malnourished individuals from low socioeconomic back grounds living in crowded and filthy environments.
  • Axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy may be present, especially with Mycobacterial infection indicating a systemic inflammatory response associated with phlyctenular conjunctivitis.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: A frequent user of contact lenses complains of acute pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision for more than two weeks that do not improve with conventional treatment. Upon examination, it is discovered that the affected eye has a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrate and underlying epithelial abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a severe corneal infection caused by the protozoan Acanthamoeba, commonly seen in frequent contact lens users.

Key clinical features:
  • Acute pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision persisting for more than two weeks despite conventional treatment.
  • Paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrate and underlying epithelial abnormalities.
  • The presence of Stromal infiltrate in the corneal stroma is a key finding in Acanthamoeba keratitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 230, 231.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from a rural area visits the ophthalmology clinic with a 10-day history of vision problems. He describes how, around 15 days prior, vegetative stuff had fallen into his left eye. Upon inspection, a corneal ulcerative lesion with feathery borders and creamy exudates is discovered. There were a few satellite lesions as well. Which is the most likely etiological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Fusarium sp.
 
  • The given scenario with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and thick hypopyon and the microscopic findings of branched, septate hyphae suggest mycotic keratitis caused by Aspergillus or Fusarium. 
  • Fusarium species are filamentous fungi commonly found in the environment, including soil and plants.
  • They can cause a severe corneal infection known as fungal keratitis
  • Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and immunocompromised individuals. It usually is caused by filamentous septate organisms such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, or yeasts such as Candida albicans.





Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: What is the wavelength of the laser used to shape the cornea in refractive surgery (in nanometers)?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: 193 nm.
 
  • Refractive surgery procedures like LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) and PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy), use an excimer laser to reshape the cornea and correct vision problems such as nearsightedness, farsightedness, and astigmatism.
  • The excimer laser emits ultraviolet light in the range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
  • The most commonly used wavelength for an excimer laser in refractive surgery is 193 nm.
  • The argon-fluorine excimer lasers emit energy at a wavelength of 193 nm. This wavelength falls in the UV-C range of the light spectrum.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 88.

questions.text: A young patient with progressive visual blurring in the left eye arrives at the ophthalmology outpatient clinic. Fine stellate keratotic precipitates, aqueous flare, and a characteristic complex posterior subcapsular cataract are all visible under the slit light. There were no posterior synechiae could be seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuch's.
 
  • Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. It is normally seen in middle-aged people who may complain of symptoms such as blurring of vision and persistent floaters.
  • Clinical findings are given in the table below.
  • Long-term monitoring is indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. 




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 775.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a limbal scar arrives at the ophthalmology clinic with noticeably impaired close and distance vision. A large and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex are all visible on clinical examination. With corrective lens of +11D, 6/6 vision is attained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Aphakia.

Aphakia refers to the absence of the crystalline lens in the eye.

The clinical findings consistent with aphakia in this case include:
  • A limbal scar.
  • Noticeably impaired close and distance vision.
  • A large and deep anterior chamber.
  • Iridodonesis (tremulousness of the iris).
  • A dark pupillary reflex.
The patient's visual impairment is attributed to the absence of the crystalline lens, and the corrective lens compensates for the refractive error caused by aphakia.
With a corrective lens of +11D, the patient achieves 6/6 vision, indicating the need for significant refractive power compensation.
Clinical findings given above are more consistent with aphakia than posterior lens dislocation.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 37, 38.

questions.text: A patient with uniocular diplopia arrives at the emergency room. A golden crescent is visible during inspection under oblique illumination, while a black crescent is visible during examination under coaxial illumination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Ectopia lentis.
 
  • Ectopia lentis is a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position. 
  • It may be partially or fully displaced. 
The clinical findings include:
  • A golden crescent visible during inspection under oblique illumination (represents the edge of the displaced lens)
  • A black crescent visible during examination under coaxial illumination (represents a shadow cast by the displaced lens)



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 334.

questions.text: An newborn exhibits a white pupillary reflex on both sides. On slit lamp examination, a spoke-like radial opacity zone is seen around the fetal nucleus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Lamellar cataract.
 
  • In the given scenario, a newborn exhibiting a white pupillary reflex on both sides and a spoke-like radial opacity zone around the fetal nucleus on slit lamp examination suggests the presence of a congenital cataract.
  • Lamellar cataract, also known as zonular or nuclear cataract, is a type of cataract that affects the central or cortical area of the lens. It is characterized by a disc-shaped opacity within the lens. The spoke-like radial opacity zone observed is a characteristic feature of lamellar cataract.
  • The white pupillary reflex (white pupil), occurs when light entering the eye is scattered or blocked by the opacity within the lens, resulting in the white appearance of the pupil during a red reflex examination.

Types of congenital cataracts:




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 335.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man who had his cataract removed and an IOL implanted 3 weeks prior complains of worsening eyesight. Slit-lamp examination reveals honeycomb maculopathy, and fluorescein angiography (FA) reveals hyperfluorescence resembling "flower petals." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Cystoid Macular Edema.
 
  • In the macula, the central part of the retina responsible for sharp, central vision.
  • In this case, the patient underwent cataract removal and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, which are common procedures performed to treat cataracts and improve vision.
  • However, the worsening eyesight and the presence of honeycomb maculopathy on slit-lamp examination are indicative of macular involvement.
  • In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance).
  • On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance".



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 627, 628, 630.

questions.text: An uncomplicated phacoemulsification with IO: implantation is performed on a 60-year-old diabetic patient. On the third postoperative day, he complained of pain, blurred vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reaction. Upon examination, aqueous cells were found to be 4+, there was hypopyon in the anterior chamber with posterior synechiae, and there was retrolental flare. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Endophthalmtis.
 
  • Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation, caused due to contamination with bacteria such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is the most common.
  • Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitiritis.
  • Endophthalmitis refers to infection/inflammation of all the inner layers of eyeball except the sclera. So it presents with a wide variety of clinical features.
  • The symptoms described by the patient, such as pain, blurred vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reaction, are consistent with the clinical presentation of endophthalmitis.
  • The presence of aqueous cells (4+), hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber), posterior synechiae (adhesion between the iris and lens or cornea), and retrolental flare (inflammation in the vitreous) further support the diagnosis of endophthalmitis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 724-726.

questions.text: What is the name of the additional layer of skin seen in the epidermis of the palms and soles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Stratum Lucidum
 
  • The additional layer of skin seen in the epidermis of the palms and soles is called Stratum Lucidum.
  • Stratum Lucidum is a translucent layer present in areas of thick skin, such as the palms and soles.
  • This layer is responsible for the clear appearance of thick skin and increases its resistance to friction and abrasion.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 145,146,147

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to sebaceous glands?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Glands of Moll
 
  • Sebaceous glands are small, oil-producing glands found throughout the skin, except on the palms and soles.
  • They secrete sebum, an oily substance that helps lubricate and waterproof the skin and hair.
  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine sweat glands that are found on the margin of the eyelid. They are not related to sebaceous glands.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 784,785

questions.text: What is the term for tiny bleeding areas in plaque psoriasis following the removal of deep scales?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Auspitz sign

Bleeding points post removal of deep scales indicate Auspitz's sign is characteristic of psoriasis.  It occurs due to suprapapillary thinning and increased vasculature to Rete ridges. 

Psoriasis:
  • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. 
  • Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.
  • The nails are frequently involved, and pitting is the most common finding seen. Nail beds can also be affected, giving rise to the oil-drop sign—a highly specific sign seen in this condition.
  • Other manifestations include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.



Nail changes seen in lichen planus and psoriasis:




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.10

questions.text: Which glands are affected by bromhidrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Apocrine Sweat Glands

Disorders of the apocrine glands are:
  • Bromhidrosis - abnormal sweat odor due to bacterial growth.
  • Chromhidrosis - secretion of vividly colored apocrine sweat (blue, yellow, or green color). It is usually of apocrine origin and seen in the axilla, areola of the nipple, or face.
  • Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria- obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 94.15, 94.16

questions.text: What causes the contact dermatitis referred to as "Scourge of India"?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Parthenium
 
  • Parthenium or Gajar Ghans is the most common invasive species in India. It is called as the “Scourge of India", scourge meaning something that causes great trouble or suffering.
  • In India, the weed Parthenium most commonly causes airborne dermatitis.
  • Many allergenic plants, especially those belonging to the Compositae (Asteraceae) family, are destroyed by cold and frosty weather, but return during the warmer spring and summer months. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 128.11

questions.text: Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris is distinguished by antibodies against?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Desmoglein 1 and 3
 
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucosa.
  • In the skin, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers.
  • In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present in lower layers.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: Where is an a 'Hanging Curtain' sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pityriasis rosea
 
  • Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms.
  • It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.
  • The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch.
  • Christmas tree pattern along cleavage lines with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign is also seen.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.90, 25.91

questions.text: Where is the "Carpet Tack" sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: DLE
 
  • Carpet tack sign or tin- tack sign, or cat's tongue sign, is seen in DLE. It means hyperkeratosis and plugging of the follicular ostia with keratotic material.
  • In cutaneous lupus erythematosus or discoid lupus erythematosus, the skin lesions present as well-defined erythematous patches with adherent scaling and peripheral hyperpigmentation. 
  • When the scale is removed its undersurface shows horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals. This is called the ‘tintack’ sign.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.4

questions.text: Which of the following are not cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gorlin’s sign

Gorlin’s sign is the ability of patients of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle.
The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:
  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of the eyelid with periorbital edema
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules
  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 53.4, 53.5

questions.text: A patient is now taking regular drugs for concomitant medical conditions. Which of the following medications can be safely discontinued with a low risk of negative consequences prior to abdominal surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. ACE Inhibitors/ACE Receptors Blockers
 
  • All long-term antihypertensive treatment should be continued up to the day of surgery, with the possible exception of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).
  • Administration of these medications within 24 hours before surgery is consistently associated with increased risks of intraoperative hypotension, and possibly associated with elevated risks of postoperative myocardial injury. Accordingly, it is reasonable to withhold these medications for 24 hours before surgery.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 929.

choices.text: Increased nicotine level may increase sympathetic tone
Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels may shift oxyhemoglobin curve to Right
Reduced pulmonary capacity may result from poor ciliary function and reduced surfactant

questions.text: All of the following statements about the effects of smoking in chronic smokers scheduled for elective surgery are true, except:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels may shift oxyhemoglobin curve to Right
 
  • Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels do not shift the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. Instead, they cause leftward shift, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin and impairing tissue oxygenation.
  • Smoking should be completely stopped in 6 weeks before surgery because complete recovery of cilia activity takes place in 6 weeks.
  • Smoking when stopped 12 hours before helps decrease nicotine (helps improve cardiac activity) and decreases carbon monoxide (decreases carboxyhemoglobin levels, shifting oxygen dissociation curve to the right and thereby improve O2 delivery to the tissues. 




Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 953, 954.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic medications should not be used in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Pethidine.
 
  • Pethidine also known as meperidine, is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, pethidine should be avoided due to its active metabolite, normeperidine, which can accumulate and cause neurotoxicity.
  • Normeperidine can lead to central nervous system excitation, seizures, and other adverse effects, particularly in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Alternative opioids with shorter or no active metabolites, such as fentanyl or sufentanil, are preferred in patients with chronic renal failure.
Anesthetic drugs in renal failure:





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 727.

questions.text: Which statement concerning Total Intra-Venous Anesthesia (TIVA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Reduces Cerebral Metabolic Rate
 
  • TIVA refers to an anesthesia technique where all anesthetic agents are administered intravenously, without the use of inhalational agents.
  • TIVA has several advantages, including precise control of anesthetic depth, rapid onset and offset of anesthesia, and reduced side effects associated with inhalational agents.
  • One of the notable benefits of TIVA is its ability to reduce cerebral metabolic rate (CMRO2), leading to cerebral protection during surgery. However, Ketamine causes mild increase in CMRO2.
  • By reducing cerebral metabolic rate, TIVA helps to minimize the brain's oxygen and energy requirements, reducing the risk of cerebral ischemia and improving patient outcomes.

Advantages of TIVA over inhaled anesthetics:
  • Smooth induction and rapid recovery with a minimal hangover
  • Low incidence of nausea and vomiting
  • Safe in patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia
  • Reduced greenhouse effect of inhalational anesthesia
  • Paralysis is not always required. Reversal agents can be avoided and emergence is rapid (especially in propofol TIVA with remifentanil).


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 656, 668, 722.

questions.text: What causes thiopentone to have a Cerebro-protective effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Decreased cerebral metabolism
 
  • The Cerebro-protective of thiopentone is primarily attributed to its ability to decrease cerebral metabolism (option A).
  • Thiopentone is an intravenous anesthetic agent commonly used for induction of anesthesia.
  • It acts by enhancing the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) on the central nervous system, leading to sedation and anesthesia.
  • By decreasing cerebral metabolism, thiopentone reduces the metabolic demands of the brain, including oxygen consumption and glucose utilization.
  • This can have a beneficial effect on the heart by improving oxygen supply-demand balance and reducing the workload on the cardiovascular system.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants produces the most discomfort during injection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Succinyl Choline

Succinylcholine causes pain on injection because it has a pH of 3.5 which is much below normal human blood pH, 7.4.
Rocuronium also causes pain it has a pH of 4.0, but as the pH of succinylcholine is lower it causes more pain.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 240.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used to assess an individual's intraoperative awareness?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Bispectral index (BIS)
 
  • BIS is a monitoring technique used to check the depth of anesthesia and assess intraoperative awareness. 
  • It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1282.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is least impacted by anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA)
 
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to sound.
  • This test is used to diagnose hearing loss and other auditory disorders.
  • The BERA test measures the electrical activity of the brainstem, which is the part of the brain that is responsible for processing auditory information.
  • The BERA  test is least impacted by anesthesia because the electrical activity of the brainstem is not significantly affected by anesthesia. In contrast, other tests such as Visual Evoked Response (VER), Somatosensory Evoked potential (SSEP), and Electroencephalogram (EEG) are more sensitive to the effects of anesthesia.
  • Visual Evoked Response (VER) measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to visual stimuli. Somatosensory Evoked potential (SSEP) measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to sensory stimuli such as touch or pressure. Electroencephalogram (EEG) measures the electrical activity of the brain in real-time and is used to diagnose neurological disorders such as epilepsy.
  • Therefore, the correct option is 1: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is least impacted by anesthesia.
Online Reference: 
Gundogdu O, Yaman H, Karaaslan P, Serbetcioglu MB. Effect of General Anesthesia on Auditory Brainstem Response Testing. Medeni Med J. 2022 Jun 23;37(2):145-149. doi: 10.4274/MMJ.galenos.2022.25741. PMID: 35734981; PMCID: PMC9234361.

questions.text: What is an ideal therapeutic radioisotope?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Strong Beta; Low Gamma emitter
Beta radiation cause mainly destruction(therapeutic) and gamma radiation mainly causes penetration (diagnostic). 
Strong beta helps in destroying the desired tissue and low gamma prevents the spread of radiation to other nearby tissues. 
  • Choosing a radionuclide for therapy may be contrasted with the ideal for diagnosis.
  • In diagnostic imaging, a radionuclide emitting gamma radiation may be desirable, whereas for treatment, non-penetrating radiations, having a short range in tissue, are required.
  • Gamma photons, when present in therapeutic agents, may contribute a radiation dose to non-target tissues and deliver an external radiation dose to other people. So isotopes emitting less gamma are preferred.
  • All current routine clinical treatments use beta emitters, although alpha-emitting radionuclides have been used in clinical trials.
  • One of the most commonly used beta emitters is Iodine-131, which also emits gamma photons. This enables the distribution in the body to be imaged with a gamma camera and can provide data for dosimetry assessments.



Penetration power of radiation- Gamma rays>X-Rays>Beta particles>alpha particles



Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 113, 114.

questions.text: Which of the following is not controlled by Kilovolt Peak (KvP)?

Density is not dependent on Kilovolt Peak (KvP). Rest all can be controlled by KvP.

questions.text: Which of the following X-ray films is most frequently used for mammography?

questions.text: Where is the Luckenschadel skull most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
• Luckenschadel skull is a dysplasia of the membranous skull vault and is associated with Chiari II malformation and Meningomyelocele
  • The Luckenschadel skull is a type of skull deformity characterized by a flattened occiput and a prominent forehead.
  • This deformity is commonly seen in cases of Arnold Chiari Malformation.
  • The downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils causes pressure on the skull, leading to the flattened occiput.
  • The prominent forehead is thought to be a compensatory mechanism to balance the skull

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Stipulated ribs
Stipulated ribs are not seen in hypothyroidism.

They are small, bony projections that can be seen on the 12th rib in people with certain conditions, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Wormian bones: Small, irregular bones that can be seen on the skull
  • Option 3-  Beaking of the vertebra: Tips of the vertebrae become enlarged and pointed. It is also known as bullet shaped vertebra
  • Option 4- Epiphyseal dysgenesis: Growth plates of the bones are affected, which can lead to short stature and other skeletal abnormalities.



Reference: Gutch, Manish et al. “Skeletal manifestations of juvenile hypothyroidism and the impact of treatment on skeletal system.” Indian journal of endocrinology and metabolism vol. 17,Suppl 1 (2013): S181-3. doi:10.4103/2230-8210.119565. questions.text: 50y old female comes to your OPD with right sided abdominal pain with history of Dyspepsia. USG was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and USG showing posterior acoustic shadowing is suggestive of Gall Stones
The features of GB stones on USG include-
  • Hyperechoic stones: Gallstones appear hyperechoic on an ultrasound. 
  • Shadowing: A posterior acoustic shadow is created by gallstones. 
  • Movement: Gallstones move when the patient changes position. 
  • Wall-echo-shadow (WES) sign: This sign indicates that the gallbladder is filled with one or more stones. The WES sign is made up of the gallbladder wall, the stone's echo, and the acoustic shadow. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 659.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1235.

questions.text: What does the blue color on the Color Doppler represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Flow away from the transducer.

 
  • Doppler ultrasound is an extended application of ultrasound based on Doppler Effect. 
  • Primarily used for vascular imaging in order to detect blood flow in blood vessels. 
  • Based on the principle of doppler effect-change in frequency of sound whenever there is relative motion between the emitter of sound and reflector of sound. 
  • Relative motion between stationary ultrasound probe which acts as emitter and moving red blood cells in arteries which act as reflectors in our body produce Doppler Effect. 
  • Color Doppler is a subjective method of Doppler interpretation. The information is color coded based on direction of flow.
  • Red color indicates blood towards the probe (positive doppler shift) whereas blue color indicates blood away from the probe (negative doppler shift). However, this red-blue color allotment is arbitrary and can be reversed. 




Reference: Carroll D, Bickle I, Chieng R, et al. Color flow Doppler (ultrasound). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-67339

questions.text: In which of the following situations are delusions not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: CONVERSION DISORDER
  • Delusions are commonly associated with Paranoid type of Schizophrenia.
  • Delusions are found in Major Depression with psychotic features.
  • Dementia can also commonly be associated with delusion.
Hence by ruling out the options Conversion Disorder is the most appropriate answer to this question.

CONVERSION DISORDER –
  • Functional Neurologic symptom disorder.
  • It is an unexplained loss of sensory or motor function.
  • Stressor is present. [Important point frequently asked ]
  • Commonly seen in females adolescents young adults.
  • Characterised by Primary gain, Secondary gain, La belle indifference, Identification ; Positive  HOOVER TEST ; Astasia abasia; Pseudo paralysis
IMPORTANT BUZZWORDS FREQUENTLY TESTED ARE:-
 
    1. LA BELLE INDIFFERENCE – Indifference towards symptoms
    2. ASTASIA ABASIA – Abnormal gait in the absence of any structural cause


    2.

questions.text: Upon presentation, a two-year-old boy has delayed speech and communication abilities. He has trouble focusing and isn't establishing any friends. He has also been seen continually gazing intently at his own hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: AUTISM
The given clinical vignette describes condition called AUTISM which belong to the spectrum of Autism Spectrum Disorders.

The buzzwords given in the question which helped us reach the diagnosis are:
  1. Delayed speech
  2. Trouble in focusing
  3. Trouble in establishing friends ( poor communication )
  4.  Continuously gazing intently at his own hands (Persistent preoccupation with objects or parts.)
A few important points to remember about AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS are:
•            They are Pervasive disorders.
•            They are characterised by impairment in social interaction and communication, delay in developing and understanding peer relationships, reduced eye contact, delayed development of speech, fixated interest, persistent preoccupation with parts of object.
•            Ambidextrous, no association with dermatoglyphics, precocious skills, mental retardation seen in 2/3 of patients. However they generally don’t have impaired cognition. {A few one liners frequently given as stems in MCQ questions}
•            This spectrum includes a number of conditions like AUTISM, RETT, ASPERGER, HELLER.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1155-1157.

questions.text: Except for____scholastic achievement is affected in all of the following.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: PICA
Among the given options PICA is the most suitable answer.

ADHD (Option 1):
  • Timeline - > 6 months
  • Age of onset - < 12 yrs
  • Presence of INATTENTIVE SYMPTOMS or/ and HYPERACTIVE or IMPULSIVE SYMPTOMS in at least 2 SETTINGS (home and school).
  • Subtypes – Predominantly Inattentive, Predominantly hyperactive, Combined symptoms of both
  • These children have normal intelligence but commonly face difficulties in school. It can also persist into adulthood.
  • ADHD kids have the risk of developing Alcoholism, Antisocial Personality Disorder.
  • Treatment – Behavioral therapy; Age <6yrs – ATOMOXETINE, α2 adrenergic agonist like CLONIDINE, GUANFACINE; Age >6yrs – Stimulant drugs can be given like METHYLPHENIDATE, AMPHETAMINES.
[VERY IMPORTANT POINT FREQUENTLY ASKED – Less than 6 yrs age stimulants cannot be given because it causes retardation of growth.]

[1 TRICK TO REMEMBER IN ADHD - 6×2=12 àTimeline: 6 months; at 2 settings; Onset before 12 yrs]

SPECIFIC LEARNING DISABILTY (Option 2):
  • Timeline > 6 months
  • Inability to acquire information of a specific subject
  • General functioning and intelligence are normal
  • Treatment – Academic support and counselling

PICA
  • Timeline >1 month
  • Repeated episodes of eating non-food substances
  • Commonly seen in children and during pregnancy
  • Can also be associated with malnutrition, iron deficiency anaemia
  • Treatment – Psychotherapy Nutritional rehabilitation SSRI
 ANXIETY (Option 3): Its self-explanatory that too much anxiety will definitely affect the scholastic performance.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1206.

questions.text: Where is General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: STRESSFUL SITUATIONS
General Adaptation Syndrome describes the physiological processes the body goes through when it is under stress. It consists of 3 stages –
  • ALARM REACTION STAGE – It refers to the initial symptoms the body experiences when under stress which includes the ‘fight or flight responses’
  • RESISTANCE STAGE - After the initial stressful event and fight-flight responses body starts to repair itself. Signs of this phase are – Irritability, Frustration, Poor concentration
EXHAUSTION STAGE – It is because the body experiences chronic stress for a prolonged period of time. Signs of this phase includes – Fatigue, burnout, Depression, Anxiety, Decreased stress tolerance.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 477.

questions.text: All of these conditions are treated with repeated transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) of the brain except ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Generalized Anxiety Disorder
 
  • Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that involves the delivery of magnetic pulses to specific regions of the brain.
  • It has been used as a treatment for various psychiatric and neurological disorders such as OCD, Depression, Acute psychosis, Schizophrenia, PTSD. 
  • It has been approved by the FDA as a treatment for major depressive disorder that has not responded to at least one antidepressant medication.
  • The magnetic pulses delivered during rTMS stimulate the prefrontal cortex, which is involved in regulating mood, and can help alleviate symptoms of depression.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 373, 1073-1074

questions.text: For no obvious reason, a woman washes her hands at least 40 times every day. What should be included in her cognitive behavioral therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: EXPOSURE AND RESPONSE PREVENTION
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called OCD – Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.
  • Management of OCD: DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases. Psychotherapy of choice- CBT
  •  Exposure and response prevention should commonly be included in the cognitive behavorial therapy in OCD.
Some important points to remember among different psychotherapies which are frequently asked in exams:-

•            PTSD --- EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing); however the most effective therapy is CBT.
•            OCD ---- CBT; ERP (Exposure Response Prevention)
•            Phobia—Systemic Desensitisation – (It includes 3 steps: - Desensitisation of stimulus, Relaxation training, graded exposure)
•            Substance Use Disorder – Motivational Interviewing]

{Regarding MCQ frequently asked PTSD – EMDR (4 letters); OCD – CBT, ERP (3 letters)} --- Trick to remember it fast.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.

choices.text: Requirement of higher dose of the substance to get the same effect
Physical and psychological reactions when a person withdraws from using the substance
Substance becomes more important than anything else in life
Usage of substance below what one intended to use

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of dependence?
questions.solution:
The incorrect option is Option 4. Usage of substance below what one intended to use 

Criteria:
  1. Usage of substance beyond what one intended to use is Loss of control .
  2. Requirement of higher dose of the substance to get the same effect-Tolerance
  3. Physical and psychological reactions when a person withdraws from using the substance -Withdrawal
  4. Substance becomes more important than anything else in life-Salience
  5. Intense physiological urge to use the substance -Craving
  6. Harmful use 
3 or more out of six features for more than or equal to 1 month indicates substance dependence.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 616, 617.

questions.text: Drug-addicted 16-year-old boy exhibits synesthesia- which allows noises to be seen while colors are heared. Which of the following is the most likely agent responsible for drug abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: LSD

The given clinical vignette describes the misuse of LSD
The following are the important points to kept in mind regarding the use of LSD:-
  • Visual Hallucinations
  • Euphoria
  • Synesthesia – It’s a condition where there is anomalous blending of senses. Stimulation of one modality produces sensation in a different modality ( as mentioned in the given question)
  • Dysphoria panic tachycardia hypertension ( in short stimulation)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 653.
